text:
Bottled 355ml (Beer Republic)
Opaque colour, small steady brownish head. Aroma has coffee and roasted malts. Medium-bodied. Roasted and coffeish. Nice taste but aftertaste is a bit empty. Maybe not so fresh bottle that some of hops have died outl

Pours a deep opaque brown with off white head. Rich roasty aroma. Smooth with roasty malt and bitter chocolate notes. Surprisingly good. 

Notes: on tap at the brewery, May 17

Many thanks to Greg for this brew! Robe noire dencre et au volume moyen. Le liquide semble couler légèrement dans mon verre et y forme une majestueuse mousse claire et dense. Arômes de malts chauffés sans fumée, de frits rouges et de houblons verts. Cest à la fois très léger et naturel. Des feuilles de houblon européen flottant à la surface dun café corsé. Liquide assez mince où le houblon apporte légèreté et élégance. Le liquide ne manque pas de corps, mais pour un stout à 7%, peut-être un peu. Du moins le taux dalcool est imperceptible pour moi. Je crois vraiment boire un stout typiquement écossais bien houblonné. Une certaine amertume se développe à la longue alors que sestompent les fruits. Finale très sèche, densité moyenne en bouche, je boirais volontiers de ce stout à la plage.
Pelican Brewing, Cannon Beach. Soft cream, tan foam, very dark espresso brown. nice bitter roast nose. Smooth, tasty light bitter malt. dark roast. Some jerky-meatiness. Smooth body. Quite nice.
Aroma is toasted malts, oats, coffee beans and vanilla. Taste is rich deep malts, carame, amd toffee. Light bitterness on finish. l

Bottle from Albertsons. I had always assumed I had tried this, and passed it by so many times. So here I am drinking #4800, celebrating with something worthy of the occasion. Thank you Pelican! So excellent, so accessible. Black, inky pour, beige fluffy head subsides to a bubbly ring. Aroma is roast grains, hints of coffee and chocolate. Taste is also the roast grain bitterness, gentle sweet undertones, dark chocolate. Dries slightly at the finish, while the bitterness lingers on and on. Just damn good....
Bottle from Vinmonopolet Sandefjord. Dark brown to black body. Foamy, brown head. Peat, smoke, coffee, roasted malt. Quite bitter. Medim body and carbonation. A bit dry.
Draught at Brewers Beer Bar, Göteborg, Sweden. Black, beige head. Chocolate and coffee aroma with some tar and liquarice. Medium to gull bodied, medium carbonation. Dry, medium bitterness.

Bottle from Ales By Mail. Pours black with a big creamy tan head. Aroma of dark roasted malts, coffee, tar and liquorice. Taste is smooth dark malts,, weak roast, bitter liquorice with a dry piney finish, outstanding creamy stout.

31.03.2017, 0,65l bottle @ home:
Big light brown slightly bubbly-creamy longlasting head. Aroma is slightly sweet sour-ish roasted, dark malts, salty caramel, minerals, chocolate, roasted grain, dark sugar, lactose, toast, grass. Taste is slightly dry sour-ish mineraly, weeds, dark malts, burnt grain, minerals, bark, harsh hops, grass, burnt toast, medicine, lactose. Longlasting harsh bitterness, light and mineraly mouthfeel. Fair enough, not really as I expected it unfortunately.
On tap at BBF. Black colour with beige head. Roasted and coffee aroma. Roasted, coffee, bitter, chocolate and slightly sweet taste. MEdium body.

Keg @ Pelican. Deep brown with a small tan head. Aroma of bakers chocolate. Toasted bread. Ashed wood and dark coffee. Flavor skews dry and moderately bitter. Some peppery hop. Toasted malt. Light espresso. Quite silky and creamy. Well executed stuff.

On tap @ Kick. Black body with a small beige head. Aroma has dark malt and coffee. Flavor is smooth dark malt, medium sweet, mild roasted malt, coffee and a hint of dark chocolate with balanced bitterness. Fine balanced body and pleasant, long lasting aftertaste. Nice one.
Kick 250217. Black color with a brown head. Aroma is lactose, sugar, coffee. Flavor is lactose, sugar, cocoa, coffee, roasted malt. Bitter coffee finish. Very nice beer.

Big ole brown head hangin in there till the bottom of my glass. Black pour. Nose of cola, dry chocolates and grain. body is middlin, creamy soft carbo with a slight tang. Chocolate and mild roast/smoke flavors, slight licorice and faint coffee notes, little bit of burnt toast. Chewy lil dry roast finish. Nice quaffer! Thanks Andre!
Fra fat på Cafe Fiasco 25 Okt 16. Svart. Filmskum med litt farge. Aroma av sjokolade. Smaken søt sjokolade med spor av krydder. OK - men i søtligste laget.

Svart och litet skum. Rostade toner, lakrits och kallt kaffe. Okej men lite trist 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On Nitro at Gourmet Haus Staudt in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is roasted malts, some coffee, mild beef jerky. Taste is smooth, tangy and finishes with a bitter coffee note. Ultimately not bad, especially for a Foreign Stout, but was expecting something a little more special.

On tap at BRewers Beer Bar. Pitch black, beige head. Smoked aroma with wood, chocolate, hint of coffee. Very creamy mouthfeel and medium dry aftertaste. Ok but something in the roasting is bothering me.

Draught at Brewers Beer Bsr cons 2016-10-30 Göteborg
AR: roasted malt, milk chocolate, 
AP: dark brown, no to little cream beige lid
F: roasted malt, instant coffee, dark chocolate

Portland International Airport - Made in Oregon Store - 22 oz bomber. Pours a tar black with a deep, dark, mocha colored head that coats the glass with nice lacing. Pleasant aroma with some coffee accents, dried fruit and chicory. Flavor has a nice dry and roasted presence to it with some day old coffee notes, some chicory, a bit of licorice and some prune-like fruitiness in the back end. Mouthfeel is dry and rich - just right for the style. Solid as expected.
On nitro. Pours black with a tan head. Roasty malt, chocolate, coffee, caramel and toffee aroma and flavors. Creamy body with a roasty chocolate finish.
Draft. Dark pour with tan head. Roasted, chocolate, dark malt aromas. Chocolate malt, dark and roasted Flavors.

Pours deep brown with a dense tan head. The aroma had think roasty smooth malt, chocolate, dark caramel and molasses. It has a rich creamy body with mild carbonation. The usage starts like the aroma and finishes drier with a touch of char. Great.
Wow. Dark black. Milky. Cappuccino. Sweet at first than dry. Dark roasted. Thx aaron!

Dark brown almost black pour with frothy beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, lactose, vanilla and hops. Taste of roasted malts, unsweetened chocolate, bitter coffee, caramel and hops. Full bodied, medium carbonation, nicely balanced, roasty bitter finish. Very nice.

Pours dirty oil black with a tan head; nice lacing. Nose is roasted malt, coffee, bittersweet chocolate. Taste is chocolate, espresso, toast, caramel, black licorice, char, vanilla bean, wood. Pleasant mouthfeel, oily, smooth without being thin. A solid, if unremarkable, offering.

Lukt: Frukter, kirsebær, sjokolade.
Utseende: Sort.
Skum/kullsyre: Tynt dekkende skum, heng langs kant.
Smak: Kirsebær, lakris og sjokolade.
Hvor: Bøker & Børst, Stavanger.

Draft to taster at source in Cannon Beach pour opaque black with thin tan head. Nose roasted malt, chocolate, some red fruit. Taste red fruit, light roast, mineral chocolate. Light bitterness from the roast.

Nitro draft to taster
Consummation: Deeply bitter coffee and chocolate
Adjunct: Aroma of caramel, burnt malt, and blackberry; dark brown with a creamy tan head; classic stout

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2017 Serving: from nitro tap at Pelican Brewing and Flying Squirrel Pizza.

Aroma: light cocoa.

Appearance: average-sized, creamy, light-brown, initial head with very good lacing and fully lasting longevity. Clear, cola-brown body.

Taste: moderately sweet initial flavor and lightly acidic and roasty finish with long duration.

Palate: full body, syrupy texture and flat carbonation.

Overall: lasting flavor that is interesting to the last gulp.

Heavily roasted and showing at least all of its 7% abv. Drinks big, for better or worse. There was an offness to the bottle that I cant quite name - ever so slight astringency perhaps? - that didnt belong. Good, but I think it can be better. Hope to try on tap one day.
Tap. Pours deep brown almost black with lasting head. Taste is roasted, dried dark fruits. Taste is the same and some coffee and some chocolate. Freshness and bitterness wellbalanced!! Very good.

From tap to glass at the Brewery at Cape Kiwanda, Pacific City, OR
Appearance: Black big brown head that slowly disappears
Aroma: chocolate, nuts
Taste: medium bitterness	
Palate: lively cabonation
Overall: Very good beer, ok to repeat, buy
Drank: May 6, 2016

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2016 22-ounce bottle poured into a pint glass. Very intense aroma of roasted coffee, strong flavors of the same as well. Really good, but so thick it is not something that could be considered easy to drink. Excellent on its own, but too filling to have with a meal.

Thanks for the bottle, Stuart! Im almost embarrassed to say that it took me forever to get around to finally opening this thing. Deep rich color produced a nice coffee with creme head. Classic stout aromas of roasted coffee and toast. Rich, dark flavors with an appropriate amount of bitterness. If anyone has had it on nitrogen I love to hear your thoughts.
Shared bottle. Pours almost black with a nice tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and malt. Taste is coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, and a bit of smoke. Very good.

Funky home brew bouquet. Pours deep brown and thick with honeycomb head. Upfront chocolate and vanilla with hints of roasted malt soon after. Medium length finish with charcoal and sweet malt.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

Black colored, medium creamy tan head, nice lacing. Aroma is of chocolate, roasted coffee, some caramel. Taste is medium sweet caramel, bit brown sugar, some dark fruits, strong chocolate, roasted malt, dry roasted coffee bitter finish and a lasting aftertaste, some burnt notes. Medium bodied, creamy, soft+ carbonation.
Bottle. Opaque dark brown color, huge brown head with good retention and solid lacing. Aroma has burnt espresso, earthy cocoa. Taste has coffee grounds, bitter chocolate, dry finish. Delicious.

Bottle
Pours black with a nice foamy tight tan head with sparse lacing. Nose of anise and char maybe a tad of baking chocolate as well. Nice smelling stout. Flavors exhibit the anise and char quite a bit. Body is lush without ever becoming cloying or surup-y. Long finish of dusty esters, slight char, burnt malt and some bitter chocolate. Great stuff!
Love the smell. Classic stout, aroma and flavor. Nice roasted coffee malts. Creamy. A+
Black pour from draft at on deck in Portland. Brown head. Malty graham earthy and cocoa. Pretty tasty shit

At cellar temperature and into a snifter. Inky black with a lasting, tight and compact tannish foam that gleams. Thickly malty aroma hinting at dark chocolate truffle, leather, tar and treacle, heavily roasted coffee bean and kelp. Much drier than expected on the palate. Quite lean to medium bodied with a heavy, roasted malt bitterness aided by peppery spice. Woody with just a touch of tar, leather, ash, roasted almonds and vanilla. Good dose of bitter/sweet dark chocolate and ristretto notes in back, powdery in feel with a soft, smooth finish. Lengthy smoky aftertaste. No hint of that ABV. This is classic in style and deadly sessionable. (7.5% ABV, 1 pint, 6fl.Oz, no date stamp, The Liquor Shed, Jandakot)

22oz bomber from Whole Foods in Kailua HI. Unsweetened baking chocolate, oatmeal, nearly burned toast, mild allspice. Motor oil dark brown, big foamy dark tan head. Very tasty, sweet thick malts, bitter aftertaste, lingering mild mineral salt aftertaste. Very well balanced and well made beer. My second beer from Pelican and Im very impressed with their offerings, Im definitely going to try more of them!

This was poured into a snifter.
The appearance was a black color with an off white to tan color-ed foamy head that dissipated within less than two minutes. Lacing was super thick and foamy, really clinging to the glass.
The smell started off with big roasty coffee beans running into delicate milk and dark chocolate tones. Light black licorice does end up rounding it out nicely.
The taste was semi-bitter with the roasty and sweet tones of the coffee and chocolate coming in to balance. Light roasty aftertaste rolled into a dry semi-sweet finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a medium on the body with a good carbonation about it - its fairly smooth and leads to a nice sipping quality about it.
Overall, as a foreign/export stout this one definitely works. Id have it again.
650ml bottle 7.5% abv poured black as with a fine frothy tan head the aroma is malt coffee chocolate taste is similar creamy smooth & bitter delicious
Draft - Nice dark roast notes with some chocolate. Jet black with a rich light brown head. Lots of roast and decent bitter chocolate.

A wonderful stout that I found at Grocery Outlet in Lincoln City Oregon, just south of the Brewery. One of the best dark beers ever in my mind. I love Pelican and buy it out at Grocery Outlet, it is that good.
Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is malt, chocolate, coffee, wood and hints of fruit. Taste is medium sweet leading to a roasty finish. Nice
From a bottle. Everything you would expect from a beer of this calibre, rich roasted flavours, chocolatey smooth, freaking delicious.

Pours black with a large head.
Nose shows roasted malt, milk chocolate, soft bready notes.
More dry roasted malt as a flavour, some bready malt and soft booze. Moreish.

On tap at the brewery. Pours black with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and light coffee, some pale malts, dough, and light bitterness. Flavor the same. Average texture. A solid stout.

Great stuff. Some of Pelicans brews miss the mark but this one is spot on. I have no idea how to describe brews like most of you folks. I have been drinking craft beers since the Reagan administration. I know what I like and this is great stuff.
Dark dark appearance, loads of bubbly tan head. Aroma of dark espresso beans, cacao, malts, wheat and oak. Solid flavor of the same components. Dark. Good first impression of Pelican.

650mL bottle from Slowbeer. 
Good looking stout - thick opaque black body, holds a firm espresso-esque head.
Rich nose - dark chocolate, espresso, toasted oats/biscuity maltiness, some fragrant spicy hops in there too.
Its a lovely smooth, silky ride on the body, full without being overtly rich, nice drying roast astringency.
Not overly complex, but what is there is well done - bitter chocolate, rich nutty malts, espresso coffee, touch of earthy hop spice. Firm bitterness, lingering dried leafy hop character.
Very good!
Bottle from pelican. Pours black with brown head. Taste is roasted malts with some chocolate and toasty.

Block like tan head dark pour aromas roast coffee malt chocolate vanilla caramel nut earthiness molasses the flavours burnt caramel roast coffee chocolate molasses a good taste but not special the finish best aftertaste bitter sweet mix a fair stout

Pours a dark black/brown with a rich tan head. The smell is molasses, roasted malt, brown sugar. The taste is coffee, roasted malt, dark fruit, molasses, brown sugar ending dry and roasty. Medium body with fairly fine, crisp carbonation.

Pelican Tsunami Stout, 7.5%, une bouteille qui coule chez Pete et Ruth. Beau stout avec une tête crémeuse qui accompagne chaque gorgée. Des cerises bien mûres, des fruits des champs, du chocolat et du café sont des parfums qui se faufilent dans mes narines. Des malts chocolatés, des petits fruits rouges, des houblons et du café viennent flatter mes papilles. En bouche, voilà un corps de moyenne densité avec un bon apport de bulles et une texture crémeuse. En arrière-goût, une amertume assumée à la fois par les malts rôtis et par les houblons en herbes.
Bottle from Mane Liquor. For the style this is pretty much bang on. Well rounded, creamy mouth feel and very dry cocoa driven stuff. Slightly grassy which adds a nice element. Tasty drop

BOTTLE. Pours solid black with foamy tan head. Nose is very subtle roasted malts. Creamy texture of dark & roasted malts through out the beer with a touch off coffee at back end. Sourced Cellarbrations @ Capel

On tap at Pelican Pub in Pacifc City. Pours a very dark brown with small off white head. The aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, burnt sugar. Medium mouth, rich malt, dark chocolate, bitter roast finish, very good.

Bottle, 11C. Bottled 1/15. Label says 7.5% ABV. Black with a tan head that fades fairly quickly but never vanishes. Aroma of mocha, roasted barley, raspberries, blackberries, some molasses. Creamy texture, just mouthfilling. Moderate sweetness, firm but not harsh roasted flavours, chocolate, vanilla, fresh berries. Bitterness creeps up. Not boozy. Not shouty or fancy. Gloriously complete.

Bomber. Rich dark chocolate aroma with roasted malt and subtle dark fruit. Pours black with a thin light brown head with good retention and lacing. Starts with rich dark chocolate flavors and light dark fruit that has a rich, full mouthfeel. Finishes silky smooth with rich roasted malt flavors that linger nicely on the palate after each sip. Tasty stout.

Bottle. Prunes and dark chocolate aroma with some scotch tape hops. Opaque black under a thin, light brown cover. Bitter chocolate flavour with some red and dried fruit and medium hops bitterness. Sweet start ends with a roasty, dry finish. Medium carbonation, medium light body, smooth and then chalky dry feel.

Bomber (7.5%) from Roths, Lancaster. Pitch black in color with dark brown foam. Strong roasted coffee in the nose. Some underlying milk sugar sweetness as well. Strong and roasty up front. Very full flavored. Finish is big on the roasted maltiness. A touch of hops in the finish, but mostly just a big roasty brew. Not as sweet as most foreign stouts Ive had, but still a very tasty brew.
Bottle. Simple and delicious. A little hop bitterness, roasted barley and chocolate. Delicate pillowy mouthfeel. Awesome.

Glass, 6 ounces, brown bottle, during the Media luncheon, trip to the Great American Beer Festival (Denver), savoured on October 3 2014; eye: black, opaque, no effervescence, no head, no lacing; nose: coffee, chocolate, roasted barley, light bittering hops; mouth: coffee, chocolate, roasted barley, light bittering hops, light lactic, finale in roasted barley with presence of coffee, below-average carbonation, mildly bitter, lightly harsh texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Verre, 6 onces, bouteille brune, lors du dîner des média, voyage au Great American Beer Festival (Denver), savourée le 3 octobre 2014; il : noire, opaque, pas deffervescence, pas de mousse, pas de dentelle; nez : café, chocolat, orge torréfiée, léger houblon amérisant; bouche : café, chocolat, orge torréfiée, léger houblon amérisant, léger lactique, finale en orge torréfiée avec présence de café, corsée, carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement amère, texture légèrement râpeuse; en résumé : bien

Perfect pre-game beer. Purchased from Beverage Warehouse in Winooski last Tuesday evening. $5.04 for the 650 mL bottle. I knew that once I had seen they carried Pelican I would be committing a disservice by ignoring it entirely. Served at 52°F. Had let it warm up a bit before consuming. 
 
To oversized snifter, it pours a mahogany/oaken-tinted dark brown with which a frothy cosmic latte-ringed head 1½ fingers in length stood. Aromas of black bread, charcoal, Midwest hops, dried mandarin orange peels, licorice root, earl grey tea, cocoa butter, melted wax, and mint sprigs. 

Tastes the same with the addition of coffee syrup, burnt sugar, aloe vera, and a pleasurable growing warmth. This is a superbly satisfying stout, but its honestly a tad too bitter. You have to concentrate in order to get anything aside from the floral hops and darkly-kilned malts. But, I am happy with my purchase of this item. Would love to replicate this in a clone (if I can track down its ingredients)

Bottle, black body, dark khaki head fades leaving decent lace. Aroma is roasted barley, coffee, raisin. Taste is roasty, cookies, raisiny molasses, cherries, coffee. Finish is slightly dry. Palate is thick, carbonation ample, maybe a bit much for style. This is a touch sweet for style, but the flavors developed are superb!

Poured from a bomber into a tulip on 08.21.14.

A: Chocolate, cocoa, and custard.

A: 3 finger tan head. Midnight black body with no red. It retains its head nicely.

T: Milk chocolate and coconut dominate. Slight roastiness and raisin are subtle.

P: Very creamy with perfect carbonation. It is on the watery side.

O: This was an easy drinking stout that had me wondering how it was not a milk or oatmeal stout. It was very creamy. The flavors were subtle but complex at the same time. They could have been stronger, though.
A good Stout, as you would expect, but not a Great Stout. Still worth drinking at any occasion.

Appearance: solid dark brown-to-black, with half a finger of khaki head, poured out of an unassuming bomber that concealed the glories therein. Aroma: melty dark chocolate, general coffee roasty notes, some black bread, maybe a bit of earthy hops. Taste: dark, bittersweet chocolate, growing sweeter and more fudgy as it warms; it doesnt get overly sweet, as the espresso notes and some gentle, slightly minty hops keep things balanced. Finish: medium-length, with lasting dry chocolate and general roast, then a whisper of pine to clean things up completely. Notes: Why, why, why was this so damn good? Everything about it seemed like it would be average, until it entered my mouth. Everything about this beer was in perfect harmony. We dont get distro of this on the East Coast, and I almost cried when the bottle was gone. Nearly perfect. Bottle from Sarah for Beersmas 2014.

Bottle. Pours very dark brown almost black with a big creamy light brown head that leaves only a little lacing. Aroma of dark roasted malts, chocolate and espresso. Medium bitter and lightly sweet, average to lively carbo, flavor of dark chocolate, creamy texture in a medium body, no taste of alcohol and a brief lightly bitter finish.

Bottle from Brewfest. Black with thick brown head and lace. Mild roasted chocolate woody spice aroma. Dark chocolate roasted coffee very mild fruit sweetness very mild tang and medium woody bitterness with hints of spice. Relatively dry for style. Creamy medium body. Dangerously quaffable and sessionable for abv without sacrificing flavor and body. Excellent.

On tap at McNallys Taproom in Hillsboro, OR. Black pour with a medium beige head and lots of lacing. Aroma of coffee and roasted malts. Mildly sweet, nice balancing bitterness, nice bitter finish. A delicious stout.

I had two of these back to back on tap with a burger at Omars. The first one was wonderful but I should have had just a glass instead of a pint on the second. It made me too full and I had fo commit to finishing. Im not really a stout drinker but everything from Pelican so far has been good. Like my friend said about drinking stout tonight, "hey, its winter."

22 pours licorice black with a thin tan head. Aroma is of chocolate malts and dark fruit. Taste is a bit one dimensional when the temperature isnt in the sweet spot, but a creamy fudge with a hint of nuts when just right. Mouthfeel is a bit thin but well balanced, not too sweet or bitter and the finish is just dry enough. Pretty solid but not spectacular.
good not great stout. nice aroma of the usual things - much roast in aroma. taste had too much roasted malt - a little too heavy for my tastes and on thinner side for stout.
From a 22 oz bottle shared at home. Pours black with a tan head. Light roasted nose. Flavors of coffee and licorice. Bitter roast finish.

A nice unique stout. Pours a very thick deep black with a thick tan head. Smells a bit of green olives of all things. Also a bit of coffee and vanilla. Taste is well balanced and very creamy. More green olives in the finish. As it opens up you get more vanilla and coffee. Had in the bottle.
Tap at Pelican Brewing in Tillamook. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is very roasty, chocolate, a little pine. Taste is medium-full, dark chocolate, dry, bitter finish. Overall, good.

I had high expectations for this beer, given how much I love pelican, but honestly it was a bit of a let down, though certainly not a bad beer. Pours a black color with light brown head. The nose is of roasted malts, fudge and molasses and dark fruit. Pretty promising nose. The mouth is much more linear with roasted malt and dark fruit. Decent bitterness.the mouth lacks the complexity of the nose. Moderately bitter finish with roasted malts.
Bottle (12oz $5.50): Nearly black with tan head. Good lacing. Medium body and carbonation. Creamy. Roasted Coffee/chocolate flavors. Some bitterness in the finish.

Sampled at GABF 2014. Pours a deep dark brown body with thin tan lacing. Aroma is soft sweet chocolate, sweet nuts and rich roast. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of roast up front, followed by chocolate, coffee, light malt and nut. Nice balance.
dark pour some tan head. Aroma choco, woody, roast salt. Tastes tannic, firm bitter on the finish. dark chocolate some soy dry palate. slight grassy hops on the tail.
Bombed from a trade. Deep dark and rich flavors. Lots of roasted malt and a bittersweet finish. Light hop fruit. Dark color with a tan head. Creamy texture. Nice well rounded stout.

On Tap at The River Room, Whole Foods Boise. Black with a very impressive dark tan head hat settled nicely into a thick sustaining ring. Served a bit cold, but plenty of classic dark roast campfire aromas. Flavors are similar with significant bitterness. For a foreign, I expected a bit less IBU and a bit more sweetness
outstanding stout. Roasty front and back end. Dark chocolate creamy nutty quality, slight leather. Very very good stout.

Well, it looks like a stout: as black as sin with only a suggestion of mahogany in the dimple of the glass and a crema of latter coloured head. It smells of stout: chocolate, dusty cocoa, licorice and some floral violet. It tastes of stout: a little charry with flaky grain and surprisingly juicy flavours. It is medium-bodied with a sherbety mouthfeel and a faintly astringent finish. 
So, my immediate thought is that this beer is a stout. Well, duh. However, it is an archetypal stout. Bang on in all the categories it should be however theres just something about it that fails to capture my imagination. I should be grateful to find it here on these foreign shores at all, but I was looking forward to something altogether chewier and fulsome. Dont get me wrong though, its lovely.

(22 oz bottle) Yes I get it. Very clever use of roasted things to give the lovely chocolate nose and body, lovely soft middleness and palate pleasing IBU levels makes this a really easy drinking beer. Not however spectacular but pretty awesome the same. Found that I didnt feel the need to have to balance this with food and on its own was good enough. Wanted it to be richer or fruiter but that would then have made me explode with happiness, as it is Id suggest get in!

22 ounce bottle from Market of Choice in Ashland, roasted chocolate aroma, bitter coffee finish, dry on the tongue. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Always good to have an American stout that does taste like a stout, and not some Jaegermeister herbal crap. Theres plenty of dark chocolates here, with some tart red fruit up on the aroma, and a nice creamy feel. Tart, bitter in the finish. Not with the vegemite/soy sauce of many other foreign stouts, but still very nice.
Licorice aroma nicely complements the tart flavour that follows. A good example of the style but many others are better.
Roasted nose. Roasted malt bitter slightly coffee. Creamy thick mouthfeel. Warming high alcohol. Addition of hops adds to an already reasonably bitter profile. Good but nothing particularly special!

Big ups to Homer321 for bringing this to RBSG to share with me, then accidentally leaving it in my cooler so that I could share it with friends in a location remote from my dining room. 
Pours black with a small head and some lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is ashy with some licorice, some black strap molasses, light chocolate, and lighter hops. 

The flavor possesses a very satisfying but somewhat bracing level of bitterness, its got molasses & dark chocolate all over the place. The beer is very roasty and mildly sweet featuring a dry-ish finish. 

A cool beer I had always wanted to dry. Thanks homie!

At prewpub in Tillamook with Taylor, Stephen, and Dina. Pours black with almost no head. Aroma is nutty roasted malt, thin, tang. Taste is creamy, nutty, marshmallow roasted malt, kinda smooth. Light and fluffy.

Poured from tap to glass. Dark hue with creamy brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, cherry, straw, molasses. Mouthfeel is nice with medium body and soft carbonation. Taste is sweet initially with astringent following and clean finish. Overall a nice shelf stout.

Bottle. Chocolate roast, light licorice aroma
Black, brown head
Dry roasted choc, coffee and licorice notes. Medium body, ultradry mouthfeel. 
Somewhat cloying, did not enjoy on the long run.

Bottle picked up in Chicago and shared with Tmoney99 in 2010. Pours dark brown to black in color with a small khaki colored head. The aroma and flavor had roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, some coffee, cookies, earthy bitterness with dark fruit and a creamy finish.
22 Oz bottle. Pours oil jet black. Thin tan head. Roasted coffee aroma. Bold tasting stout which I like. Nothing really sweet about it. Dark chocolate and dark roasted coffee flavor. Great stout.

Bottle at home finishing up Oregon week. Pours jet black with nice head. Nose is malty and of coffee. Tasted ofmroasted malt, chocolate, woody, sling cola, grapefruit, and licorice. Slight powdery texture. Quite decent not too sweet stout.
22oz and on tap a few times around the PacNW. Rich, roasty, and nicely flavored in the grain department, this brew is solid.

On tap, pours deep coffee black with a tight tan head, lots of lacing. Big espresso nose, roasted grain, some plumb? Great classic stout flavors, coffee, bitter chocolates, with a long dry finish. Yumm!

First off this is a beautiful beer, perfect in appearance for a stout. It is deep black w/ a creamy off-white head that lasts the duration of a pint-sized pour. The beer, overall, is not quite as good as it looks but, hey, how many things are perfect? It is chocolaty and roast w/ a rather mild nose. A very slight touch of tartness and a bit of sweetness bring out some raisin-like malt. It finishes dry and clean w/ a lingering coffee tote on the tongue. My main problem with this, as far as I have one, is that its over seven percent alcohol but doesnt really taste big enough to justify that strength. If it werent for a little bit of alcohol heat, Id have had no idea this wasnt a (rather good) session stout. On the other hand, I do suppose this is relatively easy drinking for a stronger beer. Overall, this is a pretty decent pour.

Bottle with thanks to Homer! Pours inky black with a medium creamy brown head that dissipates slowly with good lacing. Aroma is roasty, ashtray, coffee, cocoa. Flavor is light sweet, medium bitter, creamy and tasty. Full body, creamy mouthfeel. Nice.

black with cream cap, thick and heavy lacing. Toasty oat nose, faint sweetness. Equally dry profile, well attenuated toast at front, roast and chocolate mid with decent dryness, thin body and zesty carbonation leads to light metal and bitterness, chocolate syrup in the finish.

A little watery up front. But quickly after rolling it around, chocolatey, toasted nut notes arise. After a few minutes, there is definitely a distinct coffee taste. After about 5 minutes that rolls away to a malty taste. Low on the hops which I like. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught at the Tap Room in Tillamook. Good light chocolate nose. Black, with smooth tan head. Creamy roast malt initial, very very chocolate notes / bittering enters in mid / smooth, sweet, and great balance in finish. Medium body. Very decent stout. Well made. More of a gentle roller than a tsunami.
Really rich and flavorful stout. Lots of smooth rich body and some great toastyness that doesnt come off as burnt. Toffee and coffee and cocoa are all there. Nicely done.
2/13/14. On tap. Pours black with a tan head. Roasted malt aromas with chocolate, spices, dark fruit. Very nice balance. Rich brew with a smooth finish.
650ml Flasche. Sehr dunkelbraunes Bier mit schöner bräunlichen Schaumkrone. Geruch angenehm röstmalzig, Kaffee, Schokolade. Geschmack nach dunkler Schokolade, Karamell, Kaffee.
tasted blind, rich and creamy, lactosy, not roasty, just dark malty flavored. its above average

Bottle. Pours a near black color with a fairly thick tan head on it. Nose is quite strong and deeply roasty, with just a little bit of sourness in there and just a hint of some dark fruits in there. Taste is more regularly roasted, and more like a typical stout in that respect. I enjoy it.

Bomber from Belmont station, thanks Steve! Sorry bro, could not wait. Pours a very dark dark brown with a brown head leaving lots of coats of lace; rich and luscious looking. Aroma has molasses, chocolate, expresso, and some fruits. Taste is of sweet caramel, bittersweet chocolate some roast and some sweet fruits. Medium to full bodied and slightly rough. Finishes nicely balanced between bitter and sweet and somewhat long. Had this a couple of times a while back it still is very good. Pelican a very solid brewery needs to distribute in the midwest!

Bottle; Pour is murky brown with a one finger, fine bubbled khaki head into this glass. It retains fairly well here, with some very light spotting present as well. The nose is grains, roasty notes - espresso, toast - this is a nice brew for sure. It just meshes well, and the flavor profile reveals that. There is a hint of chocolate, espresso, very modest dark fruit, with some bready malts and spent grains present near the finish. Anyway - i enjoyed this one for sure
Dark black with a thin tan head. Lots of malt roastiness - more coffee than chocolate flavors going on. Tons of malt overpower most of the hop flavors with the finish being an nice burnt bitterness.

Bomber. Pours a dark black color with a small head. Nose is roasted malt and deep rich chocolate. Taste is deep very rich chocolate with some subtle espresso notes. Full of flavor and drinks rather easily. Finishes on the palate with sweet roasted chocolate , cocoa notes. Nice. Quaff Score 8 / 10
Pours black with a brown head and nice sweet chocolate aroma. All sweet chocolate, creamy with vanilla, coffee, and roasted malt leading to a burnt, sweet cocoa finish. Delicious stout
At a tasting at KyotoLeftys place. A dark brown oily pour with a thick pungeant wine like edge to the solid stout taste.
Bottle. Ccoa, coffee, very malty nose. Nice rich flavor, good chocolate, coffee, good roast. Lightnbody, full flavor. Graham crackers. Very tasty malts, good bitterness. Light, tasty.

Really liked this one. Aroma was full of roasted grains. Appearance dark stout, typical color. Taste was really good nicely balanced, not too roasty, malty, or bitter, just right. Great beer, just wrong side of the country. If it was local it would be a regular buy.

Tap at Pelican brewpub. Pours an opaque bloack with higher foam. Great lacing. Nose is richer roast, sea brine, umami. Taste is soil, roast, earth, bitter bakers chocolate. Palate is clean, lighter than expected. Nice bitterness. Tailor made for a GABF entry.
Tap at the Pelican brewpub. Black pour with some head and lacing. Aroma and taste of chocolate, roasted malt and coffee. Smooth and light carb.

Bottle. Pours black with thick mocha head. Smell is sweet chocolate, caramel, roasted malts, dark chocolate. Taste is dark dark roasted malts, dark chocolate, sweet chocolate, some coffee. Tinge of hop bite in the end. This is really solid. In the days of summer time saisons and lighter offerings, this was a nice mix up. But a really good stout.
On tap at the brewery. Black with a brown head. Aroma of slight chocolate and roast. Sweet, sugar-like flavor. Mouthfeel is full, rich and creamy.

Drank on tap at the Pelican Pub. Was expecting more given the reviews here on Ratebeer, but was underwhelmed. Low carbonation (which I actually like, but it couldnt retain much of a head), and it tasted rather forgettable. Definitely not a Rogue!

August 2012 bottle. Black pour with a quickly fading brown head. Roast, cocoa, bitter chocolate, and oat in the aroma. Bitter chocolate dominates the flavor with richer cocoa notes, roast, oat, the sligtest twinge of malt sweetness, and perhaps some complimentary hop bitterness underneath the roast through the finish. Clean mouthfeel. Big on flavor with relatively low ABV and well-made - excellent beer.
Enjoyed this one while sitting on the beach at Pelican. Black, rich, full, roasty, chocolate, coffee, full body and some roasty bitterness to back. Full Nd medium sweet. fantastic. love.

Bottle from 5000!  Thanks Andre!!  Pours a near black color with garnet hues and a trim espresso head that settles to rim the glass.  Aroma is chocolate, fudge brownie goodness.  Taste is semi-sweet with plenty of roast and a touch of bitterness.   Coffee-like.  Medium bodied with a somewhat creamy texture.  Easy to drink and quite good.
Almost pitch black, little cap. Aroma is dark chocolate, coffee, nuts, touch of lactose. Taste is bitter dark chocolate, coffee, grains. So friggin' good.

Bomber: Black as black with a creamy tobacco head. Mild molasses aroma. Velvet feel & full bodied. Tastes of cacao nibs with a slight tart but well toasted, lingering finish. ~m

--RaucusBacchus

Bottle - pours deep black with medium tan head.  Nose of smoke and chocolate.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Taste of smoke, malt, and dark chocolate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap. Black with a tan head. Scent is roasted malts and coffee. Taste is roasted malts, touch of fruit and coffee.

2012 22oz bottle poured into a tulip.  Pours dark black with a small beige head.  Nose is roast, malts, licorice.  Flavor is dominated by stale coffee but there is some chocolate and roast in there as well.  Not great.
Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Big ash and nut aroma. Taste is very hoppy and ash. Not a lot of chocolate

Bomber thanks to GothGargoyle! A nice foamy tan head hits on top of a pitch black body. Aroma is coffee, smoke, roast malt and mild fruit. Taste is bitter chocolate, some smokiness, light coffee.  Medium body, medium carbonation.  A nice, but not extraordinary beer.  Very easy drinking though.

Bomber bottle: Pours black with a thin light brown head that is mostly lasting leaving nice lacing. Roasty aroma is coffee beans with hints of chocolate. Flavor is roasty with hints of chocolate and liquorice finishing with a creamy texture of expresso. Full body and well balanced.

Solid black with a minimal pale head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malts, liquorice, dates, figs, soy sauce. Medium body, roasty bitter on the palate with an umami and slightly astringent finish. Taste is espresso, dark chocolate, almond, black peppercorn, grains of paradise. Could do with a little more maltiness for balance.

Pours a dark black with a creamy brown head. The nose is roasted malts, coffee, anise, and biscuit. The flavor is roasted malt, bitter sweet chocolate, licorice and robust bitter coffee. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Serving: 22 oz. bottle from 5000.  Thanks Andre!  Dark brown pour.  Dry roasty nose with mineral and earth notes.  Slightly dull flavor wise.  Earthy with burnt malt, flint, and light dark chocolate notes.  Medium to full body.  Solid but not mind blowing.

Bomber shared by Elwood, I think. Pours a clear dark brown color with a thin frothy tan head. Decent head retention. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, clay, faint fruity notes. The taste is chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla, mild earthy notes and a faint lingering bitterness. Medium bodied, quite nice.

Poured from a 22 ounce bottle from a generous trader. Pours a darker brown to black with a nice sized khaki colored head of foam. Aroma has some nice sweet notes with some licorice and brown sugar. Taste is earthily sweet. Thicker mouthfeel. Pretty good beer.
On draught at Pelican Pub. Obsidian in color, with rich flavors like dark chocolate and coffee.

2012 bottle. Pours inky black with a creamy khaki head. Aroma of roasted malt, biscuit, graham crackers and a bit of licorice. Bitter taste of unsweetened baking chocolate that transitions into stale coffee as the beer warms. Smooth palate, but a very quick and dry finish. Meh.

22oz Bottle. The pour was a pitch jet black with an average (1-2 finger) light cocoa brown rocky head that was mostly diminishing, down to a thin film and small collar with poor runny lacing.

The aroma was very robust of a burnt biscuit mat, light resin hops and a strong earthy yeast with notes of dark chocolate, roasted coffee, molasses, vanilla, a mild smokiness and a slight alcohol tinge.

The taste was bitter sweet with a nice malty feel and had notes of bitter chocolate and molasses from the beginning, progressing slightly into a purely bitter taste with a huge coffee presence and a mild smoky finish. The flavor lasted a very long time after the swallow with a bold smooth bitter coffee taste left to linger for quit a while.

Mouthfeel was full in body with a dry, oily texture and a solid medium carbonation. 

Overall this was a boldly robust brew with a strong bitter mocha / coffee taste that is offset slightly by a mild sweetness, and was done very well may I say. Making this a very enjoyable tasty brew with a superb drinkability...

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a black body with a finger-width, dense and creamy, dark brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is creamy and roasty with some coffee and cream notes and a rich dark chocolate malt backing. Touches of tobacco, a light earth and pine hopping, and a hint of dark fruit. Flavor is similar. Creamy dark chocolates with a bunch of roasts and a nice coffee and cream essence. Some earth and a light pine presence that balances the rich and creamy malts while playing off the roasts well. Finishes dry with some tobacco notes to the roasts, a medium-light bitterness, coffee and cream, and lots of dark chocolate malts. Lengthy aftertaste following a creamy, full body and a soft, creamy, medium-light carbonation. Overall, an excellent Foreign Stout. Creamy, rich, and roasty with a great balance. Loved this one.

22oz bomber pours pure darkness with a thin mocha head of foam. The aroma offers up earthy to dark roasted maltiness as well as lesser amounts of burnt malts and chocolate malt balls. The taste is similar with rich dark roasted malt goodness, molasses infused earthy malts, chocolate malt balls and a sliver of spicy black licorice. Wow! The flavors just keep enhancing each other in harmony. I love this stuff.

Bottle from trade with michaelinwa.  Pours a pitch black color with a small amount of head that faded quickly.  Aroma is mostly dark roasted malt with hints of cream, chocolate, and anise.  Taste is slightly sweet with a big roasty flavor that does not overpower.  There is a nice balance there with the hop bitterness, chocolate, and creaminess.  Even a slight espresso flavor seems to show up in the finish.  Full body with a silky, somewhat oily mouthfeel.  This is a really good foreign stout.  Thanks Mike.

22 oz bottle. Appearance: oil black with a big but quickly dissipating khaki head.  Aroma: dry roast, tobacco, and chocolate and just the smallest touch of dark dried fruit. Taste: roasted malt, coffee, tobacco, dark chocolate, anise, finishing with coffee and hoppy bitterness.  Mouthfeel: medium slick body and carbonation. Overall:  this is a really awesome complex foreign stout.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz bomber purchased online from LetsPour.com. Btld 082212. The pour is opaque black with a three inch khaki head, which is very solid and lasting. The aroma is dry roast, tobacco, and pine hops. Some dry dark chocolate in there too. The taste is the roast malt right away, bit dark chocolate and a nice amount of pine hops to provide balancve and the dry out the finish which also shows a pleasant touch of anise. Taste is fresh, smooth, really nicely blended flavors. The palate is medium bodied, with soft full natural active carbonation and a great pine and mineral finish.  Manages the 7% abv exceptionally well.  Really delicious stout.

Deep black pour with a bit of tight brown head. The aroma is awesome. Roasted barley and some darker toasted malt as well. A bit of dark chocolate and some nice lingering bitterness. Really damn tasty brew.
Black with thick beige head. Aroma of Godfrey, chocolate and graham cracker. Smooth palate with toasted malt, tobacco and star anisebut nothing quite distinguishing from other quality stouts.
Bottled.  Poured brown to black, seriously roasted malts, actually not as heavy bodied as I thought, light espresso finish,  Good.
Draft. Blackish beer with a dark tan head. Light malt aroma. Roast and light caramel flavor. Medium bodied. Roast and light coffee lingers with light caramel.

650ml bomber from 99 Bottles in Federal Way, WA pours deep black color with a 2 finger creamy beige head with good retention and leaving some decent lacing.  Aroma is chocolate and coffee with roasted barley and some light hops.  Taste is chocolate malty sweetness with a roasted barley and coffee bitterness with some hops detectable in the finish.  Medium bodied with light carbonation.  A rather enjoyable brew with well balanced body and flavors.
Tap. Very dark with thin tan head and decent lacing. Nice aromas of worst coffee and cocoa. Nice dry today flavor and not too sweet. Fairly light bodied and nice dry finish.

pours black with a large brown head, and great lacing.

smell is of cocoa, roasted malt, and hops.

taste is of bakers chocolate, milk chocolate, bitter, malt, a touch of caramel, and some roastiness.  ends dry and a little bitter.
From notes, Bottle, dark black color, aroma is sweet carnal malt coco hops smells really good, taste O-Ya all the same as aroma, Good Stout I want More of this one great job Pelican Pub.

Bottle: Dark, jet black with a tan head.  Sweet aromas of malts, tanginess, and cardboard.  Flavors of chocolate malt with a full body and thin aftertaste.  A bitter trailer for the finish which follows sweetness, which I appreciate.

Nice, roasted, parched soy nut aroma, lightly sweet.  Inky, good painted bomber.  Nicely bitter - a good mix of roast and hops.  Strongly bitter coffee aftertaste.  Slightly heavy body.  Mostly dry, a little black pepper, very slightly herbal, bitter cocoa.  Thanks to Triock for hauling this back from his northwest vacation and sharing with the office.

22 ounce bottle poured a dark brown, almost black color, aromas of roast, light chocolate, light hops, and some ash.  Flavors are the same, nice aftertaste of roast, and light bitterness, made me want more after each sip.
Dark chocolate, toasted malt and a bit of licorice with a nice bittersweet finish. Best brew we sampled at Pelican.

Black with quickly dissipating milkshake head. Nose of coconut, confectioners sugar, nougat.  Medium heavy body, with good carbonation.  Dry up front sweet in back.  Notes of smoke, lactose, milk chocolate, somewhat roasty.  Well built, very enjoyable.

65 cl bottle @ hotel room, Seattle
Aroma is slightly sweet with cocoa, chocolate, coffee and some licorice. Flavour is roasted with coffee, somewhat salty licorice and hints of dark chocolate. Feels a bit watery on some sips. Could be also Dry or Imperial Stout. The sweetness starts to disturb at the end of the glass.
170712. Bottle from By the bottle, vancouver, wa. Pours black with a really nice brown head. Aroma roasted malts, coffee, chocolate. Medium dry bodied. Not Bad.

65 cl bottle @ Hotel room, Seattle.
Pours pitch black color with small beige head. Aroma of dark toasted malts, dark chocolate, caramel and coffee notes. Flavor of dark dry chocolate, dark roasted malts, hints of chocolate, dark fruit notes and caramel. Smootish malty palate with a bitter dry chocolaty finish.

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating.  Pours pitch black color with a nice 2 finger dense tan head with awesome retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Some good spotty lacing clings to the glass.  Aromas of big milk chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, coffee, molasses, toast, light fruitiness, and light herbal hops.  Very nice and pleasant aromas with good strength and balance.  Taste of big dark chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, caramel, toast, toffee, light char, and light herbal hops. Roasty, nice stout. A little thin for my liking, but overall pretty solid. A little surprised this has a 99 rating.  Good but not great.

From a 22- oz bomber. Poured black.  Big tan head.  Good lacing. Nose of dark chocolate malts and some coffee. Full body. Smooth creamy mouthfeel. The flavor is a complex mix of coffee, chocolate, and lots of hop flavors. The finish is full of flavors and is dry and hoppy.  Superb brew.

22oz bottled February 2012.  Served at cellar temperature.

Pours black with a three finger brown head that leaves some sheets of lacing and holds a nice thick cap.

Aroma is musty cardboard, hints of cocoa, dark fruit, and roasted malt.  Moderate strength.

Flavor is roasted malts, some chocolate, a bit of coffee and dark fruit, cardboard, mineral notes, minimal alcohol.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied, creamy, soft carbonation.

This beer wants to be good, but is falling short with some apparent oxidation issues.  Flavor is OK...aroma is not...

Bomber, pours all-black, nice cappuccino head. Spots of lacing. Nose is big coffee, some banana, monkey bread, bit of salt. More coffee on the tongue, with a bit of chocolate, sea-salt brininess. Really interesting stout, and top notch to boot.

Black with decent, dissipating, creamy, brown head / Reserved but elegant nose of cigar box, coffee, and chocolate / Medium body, very chewy, hint of sweetness but mostly dry, a touch light on the fruit but overall fine balance and good, bitter finish / Flavors of cigar box, bittersweet chocolate, dark roast coffee, caramel, and wood / This is an easy drinking, stylish stout.

On tap at the brewery.  Pours a deep dark black, thick and dense coffee colored head.  Aroma is roast, dark chocolate, coffee, cocoa powder, and a mild dark toffee.  Taste is exceptional, very smooth roastiness up front with a complex mixture of dark cocoa beans, medium caramel, earthy coffee and a hint of black licorice-like qualities. A full mouthfeel compliments the bittersweet balance. The dark brown lacing is very appealing.  This is a very big beer and can be overwhelming in large quantities.

Bottle poured a dark brown bordering on black with a covering of dark tan head that fell right off. Aroma has coffee grinds, roasted malt, creamy chocolate, and some nuts. mouth feel is medium with good coating and medium carbonation. Flavor has roasted malt, some bitterness, baking chocolate, underlying green hops, light heat, and a lingering finish.

Solid black, frothy brown head. Aroma of roasted coffee beans and milky sweetness. Taste is an excellent balance of bitter roasted and sweet malt, nice bitter finish. Smooth texture, soft carbonation. This beer is awesome.

Deep brown pour with a nice tan head.  Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, slight coffee, maybe some caramel sweetness.  Flavor is bittersweet chocolate, roasted malt, coffee with a little condensed milk, beautiful smooth mouthfeel.  Tasty stout.  Very good.

Bomber. Pitch black with a solid inch of creamy light brown head. Predominately roasted malt and caramel in the aroma with a bit of chocolate and toffee in the background. Taste is similar with a good dose of bittersweet chocolate, brown sugar and mocha at the start along with plenty of roast malt throughout and some rum toward the end. Mouthfeel is creamy and full-bodied with a bitter, smoky finish. Overall flavor is rich and roasty but still manages to be smooth, balanced and easy to knock back.

From notes.  First reviewed 6/15/2009Poured from a 22 oz bottle into a pint glass.

Tsunami Stout pours a strong coffee and molasses color, with only a few rays sneaking through the cusp when held up to the light. A modest tan head provides a nice finish to a solid looking beer.

Strong mocha aroma, with hazelnut and light coffee notes along for the ride.

Bitter chocolate and a touch of espresso dominate the dark, roasted malt. Coffee infused hops finish out the robust taste. 

A little bit creamy, but still with a fair amount of carbonation. The carbonation endures from the pour to the last sip. Despite the strong taste, it has a balanced feel on the tongue, leaving just a light coffee bitterness at the end.

This is a beer I could definitely enjoy as a slow sipper for one or two, maybe less of a session beer. The robust but simple flavor would cease to interest me after a few.

Dark black with a thin tan head.  Lots of malt roastiness - more coffee than chocolate flavors going on.  Tons of malt overpower most of the hop flavors with the finish being an nice burnt bitterness.
Great brew. Pretty heavy chocolate on draft not as much in the bottle. This is one of my wifes favorite beers so it will always be in supply at home.
Dark, dark pour. Very chocolate smelling, coco. Mild bodied. A lot of coffee. Rich layer of flavor mixed with good imperials here. Good job.
22 ounce bottle. Big black pour. Rich chocolate roast aroma and taste. Not a big body to it, though. Would like more in the body. But tasty.
Fairly typical stout. Nothing really wrong with it, but its another very roasty, burnt, moderately bitter brew. Doesnt really stand out for me, and would opt for others over this.

22oz bottle, shared by dwm1034. Thanks! Pours a jet black color with a tan head and a little lacing. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, a little nutty. Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is bittersweet, Chocolate, molasses, a little bit of alcohol, with a sweet, chocolate finish. Tasty.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2013 Bomber split with sherm1016 .... Pours almost black with tan thin head..nose is chocolate  initial blast with a bit of boozey sniff as it warms...initial taste is also chocolate / cocoa.  Really like the thick / warm feel of this.  Sorry this will be hard to get here in the midwest...need to get another trip in to Portland.  Very tasty.

Bottle @ Oliver Twist.
Black with a bigger foamy brown head that leaves a thin spiderweb kind of lace.

Nice roasted aroma with lots of roasted malt, coffee and cocoa powder. Theres a bit of milk powder in there and some berries in the back ground.

Soft sweet chocolate in the taste with rich dark roasted dry notes of coffee and cocoa with a hint of berries.

With all those powerful dark flavors it comes out a little weak in body, but I think its more a trick of the mind since the flavors make you think more of an imperial stout. This is flavorful and tasty stuff!
2010 bottle from bitbucket in trade, velvety black color with tan foam ring, bakers chocolate aroam with chcocolate pie filling flavor, creamy yet dry mouthfeel, some burnt cocoa on the finish

(bottle) pours black with a small brown head. The aroma holds medium roast that brings coffee alongside light dark fruits, dark syrup, earthy/citric/light hops, burned wood, light vanilla, soft mint and liquorice candy and alcohol. The flavour is light to medium sweet, near medium bitter and light acidic on the finish. Tones of coffee, cocoa, light dark fruits, spicy brown sugar, light syrup, blackberries, resin, citrus and liquorice. The mourhfeel round, clean and light sticky with near medium carbonation. Really hoppy finish with a dash of roast. Medium bodied.
Boy this is thick. Black with a dark tan head. Chewy and a bit chocolaty, some bitterness. Its quite good but very thick.

Bottle shared by phaleslu. Thanks Peter. Pours black with a light tan head. Aroma is dark chocolate, roasted malts and coffee. Flavor is molasses, coffee, dark chocolate and roasted malts. Medium bodied with a nice roasty finish.

A truly classic stout delicious ice cold or near room temperature. Pairs well with rare meat and fresh vegetables. The only caveat is that, like guinness, it should be drank from a glass after a proper pour.

Pour is thick black with nice creamy tan head, aroma has notes of coffee and chocolate, some dark fruit, anise and roast, hints of caramel and molasses as well.  Taste is a nice mix of roasted coffee and sweet dark fruit, some chocolate and caramel add some complexity, hints of bitter earth, finishes fairly smooth and bitter.  Nicely done!
For the most part this an above average stout.  Awesome appearance, thick black and dark brown head. Bitter aftertaste. Lots grainy oatmeal stout-like flavors.  Mehhh

22 oz. bottle from the brewery. Glad I finally opened this. Pours a dark, opaque brown with a small tan ring for a head. Aroma of chocolate, toasted malts, coffee, cream, sugar, and a hint of spice. Flavor of roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, cola, earth, cream, and almost-burnt toast. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a roasty mouthfeel. Not exactly complex or particularly new or different. Just damn good at what it does. Very nice.

(Flasche) Undurchsichtige "schwarze" Farbe mit mittelfeiner braunen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist leicht käsig, wird dann cremig und rauchig und wird dann caramellig und breiter stärker Bitter. Alles in allem ein leckeres Stout.

(bottle) pours a pitch black colour with a frothy brown head. aroma of white pepper, powdered sugar, dark chocolate, coffee, grass and caramel. flavour is dominantly roasty, slightly sweet, with big notes of milk chocolate and coffee. medium-bodied with soft carbonation and a heavy roasted-bitter finish.

This poured a medium to dark brown color with a beige head. Aroma was medium roast, mlighter chioclate and some dark berries. Flavor was a tiny bit of molasses, dark fruits and roasty chocolate, Pretty good.

Fall 2011 Ratebeer gathering. +++ Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a small tan head that faded instantly. The aroma was sweet vanilla, chocolate syrup, port wine and raspberry. The flavor was sweetish, tangy and nutty with notes of cherry, vanilla, and sour toasted hazelnuts. The finish was long with cherry, vanilla and toasty malts. Moderately full bodied. Excellent.
Dark black, tan cover.  Aroma is dark fruit, chocolate.  Taste is again dark fruits, currant, dark cocoa.

Bottle from Belmont Station. Pours black with a thick rich tan head and a light charred ash aroma. There is a smooth dark chocolate and treacle flavor with a dry finish and a roasted coffee aftertaste.

GABF 2011.  Dark black with a thin tan head.  Dry roasted black malt aroma with a touch of chocolate.  Dry body with a flavor similar to the nose, just too uncomplex.  Heavy on malt, dry, medium-full body with a long linger.
Sample @ SBWF 2011. This ones all about coffe. First some regular coffee then coffee beans in the aftertase. Dry finish. Also some chocoalte and vanilla notes.
A perfect balance between dry and sweet stout with a slightly burnt finish.

Poured from a 22 oz bomber with a 1/2 inch tan head. 

A great nose that is full of malty sweetness and toffee flavors.

As others have mentioned, the taste is somewhat betrayed by the nose. There is not quite as much sweetness in this stout as the nose implies. However, the taste is well-balanced with a big malt flavor and subtle hints of smoke and dark chocolate. The finish is bitter, but once again, balanced enough to create a very pleasing overall experience. This is a well-crafted stout that I will definitely drink again.
Sampled in a 22oz bottle. Pours nice and deep black. A bit of a head on it but not much. Really tasty stout. Full of great malts.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of chocolate, malt, cream, light coffee, and slight roasting.  Poured pitch black in color with a medium-sized, creamy, dense, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Sparkling.  Good to very good lacing.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and lightly bitter. Tastes of malt, roasting, tar, char, cream, chocolate, light piney hops, and some coffee.  Medium to full body.  Smooth, creamy, then dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, roast, char, tar, chocolate finish.

Aroma is strong and oily with tones of coffee and unsweet chocolate and an overtone of molasses. It pours a deep, warm sable with a thick chocolaty brown head - would have gotten a perfect score in this department if the head had been a little more persistent. Flavor is smoky and sweet, tones of quality coffee, molasses and licorice with a touch of chocolate. Texture is smooth and fizzy, a teensy thin for a stout but still good.

roast malt, pure in its natural complexity, burnt & bittersweet aroma. opaque darkest brown body with thick khaki head. a modest  sourness in the flavor,  with a jagged resin-grapefruit bitterness, roasted malt & molasses. not a big stout fan but this is finer than most, fine balance.

On tap @ Pelican. Dark brown almost black with a creamy, tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, dark roasted malt and light licorice. Flavor is bitter chocolate and hops with a rich coffee and roasted malt. Full body with soft carbonation and a dry, chalky mouth feel. This is a great foreign stout, tons of rich malt flavor and pretty drinkable.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2011 Bottle bought at the brewery in Nov 2010. Oozed out of the bottle - pure black with a small bubbly brown cap that dies off and barely lives on. Nice soothing aroma. Oatmeal, vanilla, chocolate, light fruit, prunes, mild burnt sugar, weak spice, roastiness - overall fairly mellow. Nice smooth and soothing flavour - nothing huge, nothing shocking or stiff or overbearing. Soft roast, chocolate, vanilla, woody earthiness ness ness, light burn, faint hops work, nuts. Fairly smooth, drying finish and malty. Nice without being massive.

On tap at Pelican in November 2010. Black hole black with a smooth, creamy, chocolatey brown swirled cap that leaves 360 deg lacing. Even the initial lacing had layered colouring. My beer has warmed up considerably since my first couple of sips - I just went outside, its 4PM, to take a couple of final photos in my MEC caving jacket and 10 minutes later Im still shaking heavily. Apparently I never fully warmed my core up after wandering around earlier. Welcoming coffee wafts around, almond, chocolate, light citrus, some biscuit. The sweet citurs is interesting and pops up here and there to separate this just a bit from the masses. Tasty and creamy - hints of spice (Medicinal? Why was that written in my notes with a bunch of question marks?), floral taste? What the hell was I taking notes of? Dull coffee, chocolate and smooth dark caramel. Full bodied and leaves a great coating. Mild coffee / choco bitterness and slightly dry.

Bottle.  Dark brown/black pour with a tan head.  Im usually not a fan of hoppy stouts, but this is an exception.  Perfectly balanced with dark roast, caramel malt, and toffee flavors that are off set by the hops.  Nothing to crazy, no barrel aging, just a damn fine stout...
Sample tray. Black with a foamy brown head. Strong malt aroma; dusty coffee and chocolate with a hint of fruit. Dark malt flavour. Full body. Dusty chocolate and a hint of dark fruit.

Bottle from boFNjackson...thanks Matthew - Man, after burning out on lots of imperial stouts, I was blown away by the simple, straightforward awesomeness of this beer. Pours deep black with a big brown head. Smells of chocolatey roast, mild and sweet, but with a burnt woodiness to give it enough character. Taste is medium roast, light char, a bit of smoke and peat, and a touch of whiskey. Man, this beer is smooth, pretty thick, creamy, and perfectly carbonated. Wow.

Bomber thanks to H1N1.
Appearance : Pitch black with a very small head. Light lacing.

Aroma : Light smoke with wood and light liquorice. Quite rich. Light molasses.

Taste : Nice smoke with roasted malt. Nice notes of vanilla. Dark chocolate too. Soft carbonation.

Overall : Very complex and tasty. Nice chocolate and vanilla notes. Nice smokey profile too. Nice surprise !

(cask @ GBBF 2010) A style of stout I like because  unique contries(in climate ) like Sri lanka and the West Indies islands brewing boozy flavourful stouts in tropical conditions is cool ; My old notes from August say this had a roasty bitterness ..notes of coffee and oil.Pretty rich , full body. I was a bit wasted as my notes repeat themselves  twice.

Sampled at SBWF-10
Almost black with a medium, beige head.
Slighlty sourish aroma with some chocolate.
Creamy and oily.
Flavour with milky chocolate.

Wow, finally getting around to uploading my final GABF 2010 tick.  About time - what a lazy ticker I am.  I asked the girl volunteering at Pelican if they had The Perfect Storm and she replied, "No, its not that bad."  She thought I was asking whether her shift was like a perfect storm of people mobbing the booth and had no idea what that beer was.  Ah, GABF volunteers.  This beer pours black in color with a one-finger tan head and decent lacing.  The aroma is roasty, chocolatey, and evident of slight sweetness with slight anise.  Nice balanced flavor.  Charry roast, dark chocolate, malty sweetness (oats?), and anise.  The mouthfeel is nicely light despite the intensity of this beer otherwise.  Average carbonation.  This is not as great as I expected it to be, but its still very good.
22 oz bottle from New Seasons - Black with a bubbly brown head.  Somewhat sweet flavor.  Smooth on the palate.  Roasty.  Nice long finish that makes the tongue tingle.

Bottle. [thanks after4ever]
Pours deep blackwith a small, creamy, off-white head that settles as a thin film. Aroma is mildly oaky, lots of roasted malts, molasses, liqourice. Medium carbonation, fine dry and mildly creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is elegantly roasted, mild piney hoppy, some coffee, molasses, mild milky chocolate sweetness. A very fine stout.

Sublime. Ive been saving this - 18 mths in fact. Subdued but rich malt aroma. Palate is to die for, rich malts meld together. Roast, char,chocolate and a sweet dark rich ummmmm roastiness....!!! Great weight and fatness. RIP the Pike River 29 - for you.

Bomber from boFNjackson - thanks, Matthew! Id been wanting to try this for a while, since Ive really enjoyed comparable regionals in Elysian Dragonstooth and Pike XXX. It didnt disappoint in the least, with a deep chewy brown pour, a fluffy layer of carbonation, and a scrumptious roasted aroma. Mouthfeel is thick like it should be, and overall its a very dry, deeply flavorful foreign stout. Nice.

Sampled at a Freetail release, bottle share. Poured a deep, dark brown with a bubbly off-white head.  Aroma is chocolaty, roasty, hints of fresh coffee.  Flavors are bakers cocoa, medium sweetness, day old coffee and some floral hops in the finish.  Smooth lingering coffee/choco finish.  Another one Ill look for.

Aroma is roasted malts, some chocolate, mild smoked wet wood, liquorice, coffee and some wooden notes. Flavour is similar with some dark dry fruits as well as mild ryebready notes.
