Black color, small head. Malty aromam licorice, cocoa and chocolate. Chocolate and cocoa flavor. Chocolate finish.

Bomber served in a Guinness pint. Great pour. Dense midnight in color with a medium sized dark tan head. Good rentention and lacing. Nose is sweet milk chocolate and roasted malt. Flavor profile matches the aroma. full-medium body, decent carbonation, thick-creamy texture, and a roasty finish. Excellent stout.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 8 Oct 2010) Black colour with frothy, pale brown head. Malty, roasted nose with chocolate, coffee and hints of smoke. Roasted, malty taste with notes of coffee, chocolate, dark bread and hints of smoke. More than medium body, creamy mouthfeel. Fairly dry with a generous cofee/cocoa bitterness. Very well balanced and quite tasty. Very nice.
Appearance is bubbly brown like a cola. Smells of sweet chocolate. Its sweet and easy to drink, chocolaty goodness with medium carbonation.

0.65 l bottle at Stockholm Beer Festival 2010. Black color with dark rusty head. The aromas of chocolate, coffee, buts, vanilla and biscuits. Smooth milk shake like chocolate and coffee flavor with toasted biscuits. Very mellow, could have firmer backbone.

(22oz bottle) dark, near black pour with lasting tan head with fine carbonation. Nose is floral, chocolate malt, and dry grains shine through as well. Taste is big dry cocoa, dark chocolate, creamy thick body, and very drinkable. The linger is downright delicious. What a fantastic foreign stout!

Bottle at SBWF 2010. 

Black with a nice tan head.

Roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Dry with a nice mouth feel. Not bad at all.
Sample at SBWF 2010. Black with a nice brown head. Very dry taste with coffee and some yeast on a medium body. Very straight-forward. Medium body.

sample from the pitcher @ GABF on 9/18/10.  pitch black pour with a small tan head which fades quickly.  huge roast nose with coffee and chocolate.  big bitter / chocolate body with roasted malts and coffee.  sweet chocolate finish.  excellent!

Sampled @ GABF!  Dark mahogany near ebony with a creamy khaki head.  Aroma of cocoa, caramel, and toffee.  Flavor is similar with lots of roasted malt and coffee.  Bitter finish.  Not very complex...a bit dull.

Pours dark cola brown with a large fizzy brown head. The aroma is chocolate, oatmeal, hint of coffee and licorice. The flavor is burnt with chocolate, coffee, and a little smoke. Its pretty dry with a nice full body and soft carbonation. Very roasted, ashy finish. A nice flavorful, palatable stout.

Courtesy of After4ever, thanks Tom. Its pitch-black with a creamy, lasting, brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, coffee and licorice. The flavour is sweet with notes of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate and licorice. Its very straightforward and charming.

Deep black pour with a thick tan head on it.  Lovely roasty aroma on it, lots of dark chocolate and coffee, a little sweet vanilla.  Very nice creamy body on it, with light char, coffee, dark chocolate, a little licorice.  Stops just short of too much black patent, lots of nice roast and char without being an ash bomb.  Great price for a great stout.
Black, thick tan head. Nice roast aroma, flavor is roast nice mouth feel. A good standard everyday stout if it werent for the price.

22 oz bottle from 16th St. Liquor in West Vancouver. Pours a dense black with effervescent light brown head that reduces to a thin cover. Aroma is noticeably sweet and roasted with some caramel and coffee slipping through. Mouthfeel is slightly fizzy. Taste is caramel, toasted malt pronounced bitterness, some coffee. Finish is lingering with sharp hops and roasted malt. Very good.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2012 Draft at GABF 2009. Nose is chocolate, chocolate, and more chocolate. Black with a medium cinnamon tan head. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, and very light bitterness. 8/4/9/4/17 4.2  Bomber from LetsPour bottled 10 9 12. Black with a huge tan head. Nose is coffee, some roast, and light chocolate. Flavor is lightly bitter, coffee, and some toasted bread.

Verre de 16 oz, au pub de Pacific City. Arômes très intenses de grains rôtis, de café et de chocolat noir. Robe noire et opaque, légère mousse et effervescence moyenne. En bouche, les céréales grillées sont très bien développées, avec de belles notes de chocolat noir et de café. Présente une belle texture bien ronde sans être trop sucrée. Finale présentant une belle sécheresse de cacao et une belle amertume. Une stout à la fois puissante et équilibrée.
Roasted malt aroma. Deep dark brown with a thick dark tan head. Light sweetness with a full and creamy texture. Long and pleasant finish.

Bottle, purchased from the brewery 2 months ago. Pours a viscous near-black with a slow-to-rise brown head. Aroma of bakers chocolate, clay, raisins, cherries, and hints of vanilla. Luxurious silky mouthfeel. Richly flavoured, with chocolate, coffee, dark fruits with nice intensity. A special beer for my 3000th rating!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 22oz bomber: Appearance - Pitch black with minimal brown head, Aroma - Roasted malt along with some caramel and spices, Taste - Big in roasted malt has some caramel and spices, but also a hint of coffee.
tap at the brewpub.  pours a darkbrown with a creamy tan head.  a really nice cold coffee, dark chocolate, milk drink with some tight roast character ta boot.   great.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured reddish black color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate toasted malt aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth dry texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met
Black,fast fading brown head.Roasty alcoholic nose.Decent dry roast profile with burnt bitterness in the finish. A very poor looking beer

Bottle. Thanks to Oakes for the trade! Pours eclipse-black, thin tan head, spotty/poor lacing. Nose is malted milk, caramel, dark fruit, mild booze. Flavors of chocolate, soy, coffee, very rich, spicy and interesting. A lovely stout.
22 oz. bottle, pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, espresso and some sweetness. Flavour follows - very smooth palate with no bitterness.
oh my, lots and lots of taste, very complex beer that looks like motor oil. very impressed.

From a bottle, pours black with a tight, creamy cappuccino head.  Really nice legs on this one.  Big, expressive nose, full of dark fruits, smokey roasted malt, bitter chocolate and a nice rich coffee bean  presence.  Surprisingly dry in the mouth, with the dominant flavor being rich, dry, just slightly bitter coffee beans.  Chocolate is completely unsweetened but not bitter.  Strange mouth feel, the thing is big but it really dries up and thins out a bit on the back palate.  Finish is odd and almost like seltzer water.  This is a strange dichotomy, some wonderful rich, dry qualities, but this completely flat, thin finish.  But as a "foreign stout" the dry, relatively light body works well.

Bomber from Belmont Station. This brew looks like cola with a frothy head that only beer can produce. The nose is roasty with hints at anise, seaweed, chicory. Palate is medium. A well balanced flavor bouquet of light-roasted coffee, chocolate and seaweed accented by a good amount of hoppiness makes this a tasty brew.

Bottle. Nice and dark with a full mocha head. Very sweet aroma. Lots of dark fruits and some malt. Flavor is fairly vague for me but what is there I really like. Sweet and roasted with lots of malty bitterness. Medium plus body with a nice long bitter finish  Id like to have this one again.

Thanks to savvy 1982 for the share! Pours black with a one inched tan head. The aroma is very tropical, with milk chocolate, exotic fruit, licorice, and salty notes. The flavor has chocolate, licorice, salt, fruit, nuts, and a slightly bitter finish. Mouth filling carbonation. Not bad, just not blowing me away.
Pours a deep dark brown color. Aromas of chocolate, espresso, and a scattering of hops. Flavor is bold bitter roast malts with a smooth chocolate like finish.

Tsunami Stout

1997 22 oz. Bottle.  7.00% ABV.

1999 22 oz. Bottle.  7.00% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Opaque dark red black color.  Rich roasted flavor with background of chocolate and coffee.  Sweet underpinnings mellow intense flavor.  Thick slightly gritty mouthfeel.  Sweet lasting finish.

2007 22 oz. Bottle.  7.00% ABV--50 IBUs.  2 @ $3.99 Each.

Thanks Santa!  Pours a black body w a nice rich tan head.  Nose is toasty with some tar, coffee, dark fruity honey.  Flavor is rich toasty malt, chalky with some rich toffee and coffee.  Lingering dark caramel and coffee finish.

courtesy of googzoid10.
pours dark brown, mid-off white head.
aroma, nice chocolate roast, hints of coffee, plenty of chocolate cocoa nibs goodness.
flavors, lots of chocolate with underlying bitetrness, plenty of roasted malts, some wonderful coffee flavors with a light bitter hops presence toward the finish. As the beer warms up, the roast gains in intensity coupled with more chocolate goodness.

Very mild aroma, almost non-existent.  Appearance is good for the type, its black with a rather dark brown head that stood up well.  Its a surprisingly sweet stout with nice flavors of chocolate, dark fruits (plums, cherries), with a hoppy finish.  It has a nice mouthfeel thanks to a medium body.

Thanks to SeaBass for this one.

A: Pours a deep dark black small khaki head. Light retention and lace.

S: Mildly roasty. Notes of coffee and chocolate.

T: Roasted malt, dark chocolate, and bitter coffee. Simple but everything comes together nicely. Not usually a big fan of the style, but this one is very well done.

M: Medium in body, smooth, light bitter finish.

D: Drinkable, tasty, approachable stout.

(22oz bottle) Purchased at Brewery Creek in Vancouver, B.C. Pours an opaque body beneath a beige, smooth head. Nose of dark chocolate and coffee. Roasted coffee grounds with bits of bitter chocolate. Dry. Thin texture and middle of the field ABV. A good stout all around.

Pours black with red edges with a thin tan head. Smooth roast barley nose, vanilla and coffee are there with the green stuff showing well too. 
Flavour is full bodied, coffee and vanilla again show prominently with a mild bitterness. It is sweet but not syrupy, harmonizing with the bitter hops. Finish is roasty and long. An example of American Stout done well.
you think you have a crap job... good roast level .. dark black .. quite clean stuff, light slick .. . a great session foreign .. . above the crowd . . what do you want? .. .

Bomber courtesy of alexsdad06.  Pours black hole black with a 2 finger creamy brown head that leaves spotty lacing.  The nose is milk chocolate, dark fruit and light roasted malt .  The taste is brunt malt, dark chocolate, light black licorice, some bittering hops and black coffee with a dry finish.  Medium bodied.  Good stout.  Thanks again Brad!
15/12/2009. Tsunami indeed. Lovely beer that reminds me a little of a mini-Rasputin. Coffee character prominent in this fantastically balanced strong stout. Not overly roasty but I like it that way.

SLC tasting bash 12-11-09 
Appearance: Pours black with a light tan head 
Aroma: Roasted malts, chocolate and coffee 
Taste: Silky mouthfeel, sweet malty taste with chocolate and coffee flavors 
Very nice.....

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2011 Medium coffee aroma, though it seems trapped.  Black, creamy tan head, thick lacing.  Strong roasty creamy body, weighted and great all around.  Wonderfully balanced.  Suh-weet.  030711  Warming aroma of dusty dark roasted malts and mild coffee.  In spite of the flavors being bold (strong roast, creamy body, heavy weight) it finishes light and soft.

22 ounce bottle thanks to the Boise guys, Ive wanted this for some time. Pours a dark brown almost black color with a large white head. The aroma is sweet chocolates, roasted malts, cocoa. A rich milky chocolate flavor, roasted malts, light fruit, very quaffable. A great creamy mouthfeel. Very nice.

Bottle. Pitch black body with a medium tan head. Aroma is full of chocolate, sweet malt and roasted malt. Burned malt, light chocolate and light tobacco backs up the sweet malt in the flavour. Very nice.

Bottle 75cl.Clear dark dark red brown color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, dark roasted, burnt, coffee, dusty. Flavor is moderate sweet and light heavy bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily - creamy, carbonation is soft. [20091123]
Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Black - brown head. Milkey, lactose, burned, coffee, vegetables, licorice, grassy, grassy, dryness, light smokey, roasted, dark chocolate, ligh hoppy.

Bottle at Papsø.
Pitch black coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Roasted aroma of dark chocolate, caramel and hops with notes of coffee.
Roasted flavour of dark chocolate, hops and coffee with notes of caramel.
Dry roasted finish.

dark brown, small light brown head.
aroma is coffe, roasted stuff, well blended, lots of coffe. faint caramel
flavor is coffee, roasted grains, sweet caramelly.

Black with a medium deep beige head. Sweet aroma with hard roasted malt, chocolate and coffee notes. Sweet flavour with burned malt, dark bitter chocolate, coffee and caramel notes. Finished dry. Nice one.

Bottled. Pitch black coloured. Dense light brown head. Roast, chocolate, sweetness, spiced, light herbs in the aroma. Flavour of roast, chocolate, cocoa, spiced, herbs, flowers and light caramel. Medium to full bodied. Dry. Has a roasty bitterness in the end. Very nice.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a thick small and tan head. Pours dark tan head. Roasted and dark chocolate. Roasted and mild wineous fruity flavoured. Roasted and smooth malty and chocolate flavoured into the finish. Lingering finish.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of mj. Pours a clear black with a vague tint of red and a creamy light brown head leaving some laces. Hard roasted malts, chocolate and vanilla. Medium body, very hard roasted malts - almost burned - again vanilla and chocolate. Very malt bitter finish. 231109

22oz bomber.

Pours an opaque black with a big tan head that recedes slowly to a hefty collar and leaves very good lacing.

Sweet aroma with dark chocolate, brown sugar and lactose. There is also a hefty amount of roasted dark malts and the overall complexity of this is pretty impressive in the nose.

The taste follows the aroma and has a solid roasted malt backbone with the chocolate and molasses sweetness layered on top. The finish is slightly dry with some espresso notes lingering for a while.

The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied for the style with soft carbonation and it all makes for an exceptionally smooth feel.

This is an exceptional stout - very complex but imminently drinkable. Color me impressed with yet another Pelican brew.

Bottle thanks to daknole. #2 marked on the cap. Black as night pour with a dark mocha head. Good retention and decent lace. Aroma of smoke, chocolate, dark fruits, dark fruits, creme, light spice and mocha. Taste is cocoa, smoke and non-super bitter coffee and some vanilla creamer. Light coconut note. Long duration of dark chocolate flavor. Creamy silky mouthfeel. Really well done!

bomber - pours thick, jet black with 1" dark brown head; nutty, sweet coffee aromas; roasty with fruit and a little on the thick side; dry and rich with lots of creamy, malty sweetness; chocolate, mild coffee and milk; very good stuff

Bottle from Sams Clybourn. Pours black/brown with tan head that fizzes away. Nose is super roasty, none of the fruity notes Id expect. Some ashy notes and minimal hops. Quite bitter and very refined. Classic.
Just what a stout should be. Complex and flavourful. Marks lost for overt alcohol and slightly medicinal hops in the finish. Otherwise, a really nice stout.

On tap at the brewery on 6/27/09.  Had high expectations for this brew and was not disappointed at all.  Pours a beautiful black with little mocha head.  Great coffee and chocolate aroma with nice earthy hops underneath.  Great sweetness up front with a very balanced bitter finish.  Just the right amount of carbonation to give a very smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle.  Pour is black with medium deep brown head.  Aroma is roasted malt, cocoa,   chocolate, hints of coffee, and vanilla bean.  Flavor is true to nose but more bitter than expected.  Finish is mocha with distant hints of hops.  Its a solid stout and easy to drink.

Pours back with a thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, and chocolate.  Bitter finish, but the flavor is actually a little sweet and it has some chocolate in it.  Really nice stout...glad Sams Wine is carrying their brews, I am going to try more.

22oz bottle 5/28/09 (Sams Wine & Spirits)-Pours dark black with a small tight tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, corn flakes, toffee, chocolate, and cookie dough. Taste is of the same with some sweetness and coffee thrown in. This full bodied brew is very well balanced and finishes with a slight bitterness. Quite tasty.

Bottle.  Pours opaque with a spare, fizzy, dark brown head, somewhat lasting with spare lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, toffee, chocolate), light hop (grass), heavy yeast (earth) with notes of smoke, oak, prune, and tar.  Full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Long duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness.  Lightly coffee and dark chocolate flavor with ashed wood.
This was really good. Dark with a nice head. Solid aroma of coffee and roastyness. Taset is smooth and sweet aith soem bitter toast and some coffee, a little light but very enjoyable.

Thanks to drewbeerme for this, Ive wanted this one for awhile.  Pours a dark black with a brown ring of a head.  Coffee, roasted malts, and notes constitute the nose.  Bitter roast flavors, chocolate that finishes dry and bitter.  Solid beer.
Rater #200!   Pours a dark brown body with a tan heads.  Chewy dark chocolate, coffee silky licorice and dark fruits.  Hints of char, raisin, and chocolate raisins.  Great beer.
Black pour with a nice brown frothy head.  Aroma is nut shells, charcoal briquettes, and metal.  Tiniest hint of sweetness on the entry with a nice dark roasted / lightly charred finish.

On tap at KLCC Microbrew Festival, where it was my favorite beer of the night. Pours out black as sin with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, light bourbon and vanilla. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, roasted malt some vanilla and dark fruit. Very dry finish, extremely satisfying.

Bottle purchased in Chicago.  Black pour.  nice tan head.  Tons of chocolate and toasted malt ont he nose with some vanilla and brown sugar.  Flavor is nice, very nice.  Chocolate, vanilla, wood, prunes and raisins.  Niiiiiice!

22 oz bottle poured into a glass from either TheEpeeist or Sams South Loop (Chicago, IL). Pours a pitch blacl opaque pour, a little thick, with moderate brownish cocoa head that laces and looks good. Aromas are reminiscent of sweet chocolate, carmel, cream and vanilla, biscuit cookies,  with roasted maltiness to balance. Sweet. Initial takes a moderate body, hitting a touch of lactic sweetness that moves to roast towards the backend. Sweet, but less sweet that a typical sweet stout. Initial shows chocolate and vanilla, with bits of carmel and sweet malts, moving back to bitterness from roasted malts and maybe a light taste of creamed coffee. This isnt very bitter, preaching a little more sweetness. However, quite palatable with good assertives discernible flavors. Dryness is nice too. This is pretty good. Finishes with chocolate and vanilla sweetness with some roasted bitterness and light dryness lingering. Very nice.

Bomber from the Sams in Downers Grove, IL - although it doesnt have "RateBeer" stamped on the label as the picture on the page might imply:  It pours a dark, dark brown body with a creamy light brown head that leaves spotty lacing in its wake.  The aroma has dark sweet malt, lightly roasted, with dry barley, licorice, and a touch of chocolate.  More of that chocolate comes across in the flavor, and it has a dryer coffee taste with a suggestion of dark stoned fruits.  Dry finish.  Not bad.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2010 One of the best, regularly brewed stout in Oregon.  Bottle...  Poured black with a light brown head.  Bourbon-esq notes in the aroma.  Dry palate with low or mellow carbonation.  Lots of smoked characters in the flavor with sweet alcohol and dark chocolate.  Candy and dark fruits in the finish.

Bottle from someone, maybe Hannont? Dont remember. I was actually thinking the other day that I should acquire this beer, then lo and behold today I opened up my closet and there it was. Carbonic, grapey, and moderately malt sweet aroma; a lot of charcoal. Flavor is chalky malts with a ton of carbonic acid and really not too much else. No hopping at all to be found. Really uncomplex, kind of tasty I guess but not very special. Nice pour though.

Bottle.  Poured a dark brown with a decent sized brown head.  Aroma of milk chocolate, coffee,  roasted malt.  Taste is also roasty, with some bitter malt notes.  FInish is smooth, creamy, and a little bitter.  Mouth is full with some carbonation.  Very nice stout.

209 Bottle - Thanks BuckeyeBoy! -  Pours a thin dark brown with virtually no head...aroma is clean chocolate and toasted malt...flavour is similar, initially light cocoa, and gains some smoke and char...decent...

22oz bomber, pours a dark brown/black with a medium brown head.  Aroma is lactose, milk chocolate, and roasted malts.  Flavor is more roasty malts, chocolate, and cocoa.  A smooth and easy drinking stout with just a touch of dryness without becoming chalky; nice stuff.
22oz bottle.  Pours darkest brown with a thin to medium tan head.  Aroma of malt sweetness and some roasty character.  Creamy chocolate malt flavor up front with a roasty coffee finish.  Very good.
22oz bottle. pours black creamy tan head. nose is roasty, milk chocolate. flavor is milky, chocolate, a bit grassy. smooth easy drinking.

22oz bottle thanks to andrew.....pours close to black with a significant light brown head.....aroma cocoa chocolate and caramel malt. not too much complexity....flavors of chocolate and mild smokiness with some accompanying roast.  smooth full mouthfeel and somewhat highly carbonated with a somewhat bitter in the finish...
tan head on a 4oz taster pour, medium sized. aroma of chocolate and coffee with some roasted malts and perhaps toffee?

Bottle in trade from msubulldog25.  Thanks!  Pours a dark black color with a lasting tan head.  Smell is richly roasted malt, and lightly chocolate like.  Taste is richly roasted dark maltiness, with a bitter-sweet chocolate and light tanginess.  Leaves a lingering almost char flavor on the palate.  Medium to slightly rich bodied and medium carbonation.  Pretty solid beer.

bottle thanks to hannont.  pitch black pour with a 1 finger espresso head.  nose of deep roasted malts and big notes of chocolate aong with some oatmeal in the back..   nice thickness and a smooth flavor of roasted malts with some chocolate and dark fruit in the finish.

22 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a creamy tan head and lacy sheeting.  Nose is dusty chocolate and grape.  Almost full body; silky smooth with a tang.  Taste is chocolate cake, espresso, caramel, dark fruits and black olive.  Finishes dry and grassy.  Delicious.

22 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with bitbucket.  Pours a dense black with a thin-moderate light brown head that barely lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left a bit of spotty lace.  Very pleasant aroma of roasted malt with some supporting notes of coffee and chocolate.  The flavor is very similar to the aroma with roasted malt and some coffee and chocolate.  Light bitterness at the finish.  Full bodied.  This stuff is dangerously easy to drink!  Excellent beer.

Bomber via trade with hannont.  Thanks Todd.  Pours black with a light brown head.  Nose is sweet  rich and malty with a lot of coffee.  Taste is sweet, rich and very full of flavor, lots of coffee, a touch of smokeyness.  Tasty tasty tasty foreign Stout.

Rating #700!!!  Bottle. Pours black with a super pretty, thick dark brown head. Aroma of coffee and rich sweet roasted malt. Flavor of roasted malt, toffee, and caramel, with a bitter chocolate finish. A nice blend of rich flavors. A top-notch foreign stout.

(22 oz. bottle via trade with explosivebeer, thanks Brandon!) Char and grass...Pours almost inky black, actually very, very dark brown with just a wisp of brownish head that recedes to the edges. Looks much like an imp stout. Aroma of plum, char, molasses, grape and almost burnt coffee. Mouthfeel fairly smooth, light oiliness, low carbonation, actually a little loose and light-feeling. Flavor starts out heavy on char with a grassiness that detracts. As it warms the grassiness abates a bit and dark chocolate, plum/grape, coffee and char emerge. Bitterness builds toward finish and leaves a bitter coffee/choccolate aftertaste. Some alcohol presence. Quite imp stout-like overall. I didnt dig the flavor and texture so much but it does have a bit of complexity.

Draught @ the brewpub. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and coffee aroma. Roasted malty bitter chocolate and coffee flavor with some hints of licorice. Also some hoppy hints. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish with some hints of bitterness in the aftertaste.

Many thanks to Bob for knocking this long-standing beer off my Want List!  Poured deep brown with lovely initial cap of tan head.. settled to a fine, but thorough dusting after a couple minutes.  The aroma picked up an intriguing combination of sweeter chocolates, oats, and some lactic character with deeper malts in the form of molasses, licorice, and coffee.. sweet and succulent overall impression.  The flavor opened with a smooth, almost buttery foray of semi-sweet cake-like chocolates, opening into a fluffy middle of milky chocolates and charred coffee.. found some herbal bitterness to brighten up the mood and accompany the dark malts through the finish.  Medium-plus bodied and velvety on the palate with just enough carbonation to keep it moving along.. complex array of malts that worked well together.. memorable finish (in the good way).  Excellent brew!
Pours a black color with brown highlights. Aroma of licorice and roasted malt. Good flavor of licorice and roasted malt. I’m not too fond of the style, but this one is nicely done.

On tap as part of the sampler tray at the Brewery. The most anticipated beer of the trip.  The aroma reveals that chocolate is going to be a primary flavor, but there is also a good dose of roast and bitterness. The flow into my mouth is silken and incredibly pleasant; delicate even.  The flavor is primarily chocolate as hinted at by the aroma.  Rich dark chocolate but smooth. The roast/hop bitterness only appears in the finish to do the clean-up that makes this so easy to drink.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2010 [1456-20080531] Bottle. Sweet coffee grounds aroma. Dark brown black body with quick off-white bubbles. Dark roasted malt flavour has very smooth bitter roast notes. Full body. Really nice roast, well made. (8/3/9/4/17) 4.1
(Post-Mondial Tasting)

[3006B-20100628] Tap. Coffee grounds roast malt aroma has a light fruit fig note. Dark dark brown red body with a long-lasting creamy tan head with some lacing. Little figgy coffee grounds flavour has a lot of roast with a finish that is less roast but comes back afterwards. Full body. Nicely balanced. (8/4/8/3/15) 3.8
(@ brewpub, Pacific City, OR)

Bottle, Thanks Mark:  YUM.  This is an oil black pour, with no head.  Aroma is charcoal, burnt coffee, chocolate malt.  Flavor is rich chocolate malts, slight toffee, coffee.  Dry finish characteristic of cocoa.  Nice hop presence here rounding out a great roasted stout.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text:
UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 In short: A superior roasted stout.  Simple but very pleasant.
How: Post-Mondial 2008 tasting session.  Bottle brought to Montreal by Dickinsonbeer
The look: Black body topped by a beige ring of foam
In long: This is a roasted one.  I got lots of burnt toasts in the flavour along with light roasted coffee.  As the beer warmed up some milk chocolate and some black chocolate came through.  Almost nothing in the fruity flavours department.  Carbonation was very active, maybe too much so, making the body feel a bit thin a giving a tickling mouthfeel.  Overall quite dry. This was a very good stout but I was hoping for more.  Nothing to turn me upside down, just a very big wave really.
Thanx to MGumby for sharing this.Poured a gloomy black color with a small tanish head.The nose was of chocolate and roastedness with hints of charcoal.This finished off with some bitterness

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2010 2010-06-28. Black body with a modest tan head and excellent lace. 4+ Flavour is nicely malty up front but quickly gives way to to a good dose of roast malt that I like up front, but it takes on more coffee like bitterness in the finish in a way that I do not care for, but it is still pretty nice. 7+ Dry roasty aroma with a base that hints at a sweeter malt character. 7+ Smooth average plus to medium bodied palate lends itself to drinkability could be slightly more full bodied for my own tastes. Very good stout. 7+/5/8/4/17 - 4.1 Sampler at the brewpub, Pacific City.2008-05-31. Black body with a modest khaki head. Mild aroma, sweet roast malt. (7+) Sweet malt flavour, mild roast throughout, mild chocolate undertones. (7+) Palate is a touch thin for my stout preferences but in this case it seems to add to the drinkability factor. A very solid full flavoured stout. Alcohol is invisible. 7/4/8/3/16 - 3.8 Bottle, Post-Mondial Tasting, Montreal
Draught.  Dark, deep brown with thin tan head.  Powerful malt actually MALT aroma,  Notes of chocolate, coffee and roast.  Full mouthed lingering finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bottle courtesy of Miketd.  Pours a pitch black with a tan head.  Has a nice smooth malt like aroma.  Tastes creamy with a smooth body and some alcohol.  Chocolate is very evident and has a nice dry aftertaste.  Good brew.

Courtesy mgumby10.  Black pour, sparse thin white head.  Chocolate, wet grain, mild hops on aroma.  Palate a bit thin for style, but still amenable.  Nice subdued roasty chocolate taste - slight hops and some alcohol heat on taste.  Nice and even, roasty but alcohol is in check.
I like the FES style, thanks Derek. Smooth drinking. Dark brown with soapy head.  Roast and malt nicely balanced, bitterness at the finish.
Bottle thanks Gumby at the Merritt Island Throwdown. Luscious looks, tan head. Aroma of smoke and chocolate. Earthy, smooth, exceptionally balanced.

Courtesy mgumby10....thanks Mike!  Pours a very dark chocolate to mahogany brown color.  A swirly tan film displays a bubbly edge, while scattered, spotty lacing dots the glass.  The nose is very well balanced, showing different chocolate varieties, dark caramel, roasty coffee, cream, and moderate earthy hops.  The flavor follows suit, with the chocolate richness turned up a notch towards full-on fudgy goodness.  Coffee and espresso add roasted flavors., while vanilla lends its signature smoothness. The body is medium-full, smooth, and creamy.  Solid brew.  Definitely near the top of the regular stouts

Courtesy of Old_Mr_Crow.  Thanks Carl!  Pours jet black with a medium lightbrown head.  Smells of profound rich chocolate, dark malts, with a touch of some dark fruits as well.  Really dug on the nose.  The flavor is of pretty rich chocolate as well, just like I like it.  Some dark malts added some bitterness to it.  Some sweet caramel shows up in the finish.  Maybe a touch of some hops are noticeable as well.  Really rich and fullfilling stout.

Merritt Island Throwdown 08: Bottle, courtesy mgumby10. Black, slightly thin tan head. Aroma is vanilla, roasted grain, chocolate malt. Medium body woth a roasted grain vanilla taste. Finishes really nice..

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Merritt Island Throwdown 08: Bottle, courtesy mgumby10. Pours a pitch black color, with a thin white head, and some nice lacing on the glass. Pure chocolate aromas, with a pure, driven maltiness. Some coffee in there, too, but masked by chocolate. Sweet flavors of rich chocolate, and a nice vanilla flavor thats prevalent throughout. Roasted finish. Easy to drink, medium-bodied. Balanced, albeit with a malty edge to it.

Courtesy of Mgumby10. Pours a dark brown with a little head. Aroma is mostly chocolate. Tastes of burnt malt, cocoa, little coffee. Finishes with a slight lactose taste. Palate is sugary and dry. Awesome brew Mike!

Sample Hotshots Feb Indy tasting - Aroma is mellow chocolate and burnt marshmallows. Pours black with a small brow head and good lacing.  Flavor is roasted chocolate malt, smoke and ash.  Palate is dry and smooth.  Tasty to be sure, but was unfortunately in the wrong place in the lineup to be fully appreciated.

Thanks to Illinismitty for this beer. A dark brown almost black pour. Coffee and smotke on the nose. A very nice smokey coffee flavor as well. Body and carbonation are full. Very dry flavor but very easy to drink. A beer I really liked. Thanks Sean.

bomber by way of kenb. a near black viscous pour with a thin cocoa colored head. robust aroma of roasty malts, chocolate, smokey coffee and hot cream. the palate is surprisingly dry and every part of the word robust (again!). MEAT, malt, chocolate, charcoal, wood and a light sourness in the middle. smokey and dry finish with some coffee as well. these all linger in the aftertaste. full bodied with an amazingly smooth creamy texture. complex and beautiful.

Thanks to Illinismitty for sharing this one from my wants list at our recent tasting.
Bold black body, with a tall mocha head.
Coffee, dark chocolate, roasty malt, and smoke aromas all swirl up from the glass
Rich, full, complex flavor with some dryness and tang in the palate.

Bottle at stevos. Pours ruby black with tan head. The aroma is espresso with a touch of raspberry and dark chocolate. The flavor is surprisingly dry, with charcoal and fireplace smoke mixed with those other typical stout tastes. Pretty good stuff.

Stevofest, courtesy of Illinismitty. Black, with a thin brown head. Aroma is coffee, wth a fruity notes - maybe like aBalsamic reduction  (I completely stole that line from Illinsmitty...). Much drier flavor than I expected - Very smoky and clean, but also very dry. Very tasty and enjoyable. I could drink a lot of this...

Sampled at Stevofest 08, courtesy of me. Aroma of dark roast, cocoa powder, and balsamic reduction. Pours black with a pale brown frothy head. Medium bodied with a soft texture. Flavor of dark roasted malts, coffee, with some sublte accents of smoke and chocolate. Finish is dry and ashy. Very well done and perhaps one of the best foreign stouts I have had.

22 oz. bottle via trade with kenb - Pours a dark brown color with a one finger thick tan head.  Light spotty lacing.  Aroma is smoked malt and dark esters.  Flavor is pretty much the same thing.  Slight lingering aftertaste.  Medium body.  A good beer.  Thanks Ken.

Pours a dark brown, with a finger width tan head that disappears rather quickly. Spotty lacing. Smokey aroma with dark esters, roasty malts. Slight chocolate, coffee, but that is very subtle. A little dry on the end, with a lingering roasty taste. Light to medium body.
user_location: Mescal Lakes (wherever that is), Arizona, USA

text: Pours as dark as a walnut wood stain.  Dark mocha head that fades.  Aroma of molasses and roasted malts.  Full body with an equally full taste of coffee and bitter dark chocolate.
GABF.  Nice dark pour with decent head.  Roasty and chocolate aromas.  Nice full flavor with bitter dark chocolate flavors and nice nutty finish.  Pretty good.

Bottle:  Poured a delicious looking black with a modest tan head.  Wonderful appearance.  Aroma of roasty tones with coffee and a little bittersweet cocoa.  Flavor is similar; lots of roasty notes and coffee.  Just a slight hint of mocha and bitters in the tail.  The flavor gave me more of the feel of a dry stout... still tasty though.  Thanks BuckeyeBoy.

Bottle provided by kmweaver. Black body with a small tan head. The nose is milk chocolate, light roast and raisins. The flavor is fairly dry with bakers chocolate, raisins and light toffee. Medium body is soft with light carbonation. A decent west coast stout, quite a surprise.

GABF 2007:    Poured pitch black and opaque with a large brown head.  Coffee aroma with notes of hazelnuts and milk chocolate.  Like Nutella ........mmmmm.  The flavor was full of coffee and roasted malt.  The finish was chocolatey.  Dry bitter finish.  Medium to full bodied.

Another great bottle from jsquire.  This is a  dark stout with a whipped tan head.  The nose is full of chocolate, vanilla and some coffee.  The taste is that of more chocolate and as it warms the chocolate becomes more defined as dark chocolate.  The vanilla is subtle and tempers the coffee bean flavors.  This is a full bodied stout with superior mouthfeel.  This is wave after wave of flavor and aroma.  OUTSTANDING!!
Rich, chocolate malt base with a sweet vanilla smoothness to it, Alcohol very evident despite the lower ABV. Dry and creamy. Slight vegetable essence from the hops, just slight.

From a 22-oz. bottle purchased at Pacific City brewery (thanks Margaret)--Poured a deep dark brown-amber-black.  Healty creamy-lively head with prominent red tones. Roasty flavor with hints of chocolate and coffee.  Somewhat aggressive with the carbonation, but not overly so. It is easy to see why this beer has won medals.

Tap @ GABF 2007
Notes of toffee, coffee, chocolate, and a slight alcohol.  Aroma is chocolate/coffee. Smooth, but fizzy.
Vanilla, chocolate, and coffee on the nose.  Pours black with a tan head. Smooth malts, vanilla and chocolate, a slightly oaky flavor.  Very nice stout.

The Dan Journal #110.  Tasted 9/25/07.  22oz bottle.  Purchased July 2005.  Blue black hue with a tight ring with an ink blot head.  Toasty coffee nose.  Stand up nose.  Really holding strong.  Good roast with a raspberry note.  Cocoa and vanilla.  After all this time this brew is still solid.  Evolving into something else, but into something good.  Moving toward the tail end though.  Sticky with cloying acidity.  Melding with time.  Im sure fresh this is amazing, but after two years, its still a substantial brew!

22 oz bottle, shared by kmweaver.  Pours a pitch black body under a small dark brown head.  Light lacing remained.  Nose is roasted and burnt malts with a light yeastiness, cocoa, and a sweet sugary note.  The flavor was heavily roasted malt with alot of burnt coffee and some chalky yeast.  Moderately bitter finish with a slightly ashy finish.  Some risidual lactose/brown sugar sweetness that add nicely to the mouthfeel without being sweet.  Mouthfeel is slightly oily with a little too much fizzy carbonation, as it kinda foamed up when it hit the tongue.  Overall, a pleasant Stout but I wish the carbonation were a little more toned down.

Poured from a 22oz Bottle thanks to kmweaver. Aroma is somewhat subdued, yet distinct in some salty coffee roast. Pours a rich black-brown, fringes mahogany, rim of tan. Dense roast flavor, cherry chocolate with toasted almond caramel, brown sugar and flan. Great dense, expressive flavor. Clean, bright, lively and fresh. All the aspects are subtly nuanced making this beer rounded and enjoyable. Some warming sensation from the background.  Hops come in nicely with suave chocolate, mint sophistication. Salty. Toothy. Beautiful attenuation, finishing crisply.

22oz bottle, courtesy of Yonkers65.  Thanks, Bruce!  Pours a very dark brown color; medium brown head with patchy, fine-bubbled lacing.  Pleasant, milk and cocoa powder in the aroma; slightly lactic and mild citrus character.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: dense, slightly acidic milk and dark chocolate notes; chewy, fluffy texture; roasted malts, with an oily smoked presence and not a whole lot of lactic tartness.  Lengthy, bitter chocolate and cocoa finish.
Thanks to skyview for sharing.  Nice brown color with a sweet roasted malt aroma.  Similar taste with a faint coffee character.

Date: 09/11/2003
Mode: Bottle
Source: Belmont Station, Portland

black, scant head, low carbonation, sweet roasted malt aroma with a strong hint of licorice, rich roasted malt flavor leading to a bitter black patent finish,

From a 22-oz bomber, via traded with kenb pours an opaque dark brown brew with a fast dissolving tan head that leaves behind a ring, some film top and a good lacing. Aroma of dark bittersweete chocolate, dark pitted fruits, roasted malt with some flowery hops. Taste is medium to full bodied, some carbonation, thick, smooth and creamy with flavors of dark chocolate, some dried coffee, molasses and a touch of vanilla. Finish has a slight hop bitterness with a dark roasted coffee aftertaste. Very tasty! Thanks again Ken.

Bomber.

Pours a nice rich black with a tawny head, lots of plums and dark chocolate on the nose. The flavor doesnt come in as sweet as I had expected, but rather as a very well rounded dry coffee-toned stout Mouthfeel is nice - heavy enough to but rich but light enough to be drinkable. Dry hop finish parts the touch of molassas through the midrange.  Nice even if not as "big" as I had been expecting.

Bomber. Deep dark chocolate and coffee aromas. Its opaque brown/black. The tan head quickly ringed. The ring leaves lace tatters. Medium to full bodied. Moderate carbonation. The flavor is coffee, burnt toast, chocolate, lightly salty. Hoppy resin seems to permeate the brew. The finish is super dry, and the bitter of coffee and hop continues forever. Whew!

Black beer, brown head. Black chocolate aroma with lovely base malt richness, vague pine and mint Yank hops, fruitcake, relatively moderate burnt toast, light soy sauce and a distinct Sabayon kind of egginess - weird. Lean yet rich base maltiness is quickly overcome by nice round roast and big bitterness which surprisingly doesnt taste like American hops. Choc-coated coffee beans and raspberry esters like Wig & Pen Imperial Stout. Basically its the PNW IPA approach to stout, and I like it a lot. Loads of intensity but remaining very drinkable. But whats with that egginess? Anchors beers have it too. Onya Linc!

Bomber. Pours opaque black with a thick and lacy tan head. Lightly sweet aroma of chocolate and coffee. Full body and moderate carbonation. Sweet chocolate taste with molasses and nuts. Piney hops show through at various points without ever competing with the roasty bitterness. Tasty!

22. Thanks, BitBucket! Awesome stuff. Been waiting to try this one for quite a while. Pours jet black with a thick, moussy tan head that falls to film eventually and leaves minimal lace. Big roasty chocolatey nose, with maybe a slight whiff of cherries when ya first crack the cap. Velvety rich body and nicely placed carb lead the attack, plenty of forward roast and chocolate follow assertively right along. Soft piney hop bitterness lingers on the finish. Great stuff. They need to find Washington distro for this one.

6/18/2007:  Pelican Tsunami Stout is near black in color with a two-finger, dense, foamy brown head.  The aroma is sweet chocolate and roasty with hints of coffee and lightly caramelized sugar (just like the crusty top of crème brûlée).  This is probably the best aroma of any foreign stout that I have had so far.  The flavor has lots of sweet chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, smooth coffee, and hints of walnut and vanilla.  Its a bit on the stronger, but alcohol is not outrightly noticeable.  The finish tastes like roasted coffee finish and there is a long-lasting, dry espresso bitterness and dark chocolate after taste.  This  beer is is very smooth and creamy and feels rich and full in the mouth.  It goes down frighteningly quick and easy for a beer of this complexity and alcohol content!  Tsunami Stout is an excellent beer.   I highly recommend it!


22 oz bottle from trade with kenb (Oct 2006).  Thanks again Ken.  I really appreciate it!  Rating #127 for this beer...
On tap at Uber. Dark black w/ big creamy brown head. Fairly heavy roast. Smooth chocolate flavor. Nice sweetness. For 7%, it packs more than you would expect.
If anyone wants a trade I will be in Pacific City in August and I can pick some up!

Deep black in colour, long lasting tan coloured head, some light lacing.  The aroma is very roasty, some liquorice, pure chocolate, sugar.  The flavour is creamy, roasty, nutty, some liquorice, dark chocolate, cold coffee, light sweetness throughout.  Creamy bitter mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes long and roasty, very creamy.  The alcohol only comes through at the very end but even then its still just a slight warmth.  Excellent body on this, wonderfully roasty.
650ml bottle obtained in a trade with <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?U target=blank>jah noth, thanks Stephen.
Opened on February 16, 2007.
No best before date.

C-Bus 7.  Dark beer with a whispy brown foam head.  Lots of dusty chocolate in the nose.  Lots of chocolate in this beer, with dusty Bakers chocolate, coffee and dark caramel.  The finish has lots of dry espresso coffee bean and some grassy hops.  Delicious.

CT7 Bottle shared by jsquire. Black pour with a tan head. Aroma of oak, cinnamon and dry chocolate. Flavors of dry coffee, chocolate and roasted malt. Medium-thick obdy with a bitter/dry finish. Nice stuff indeed.

C-bus 7.  Chocolate aroma with hints of roasted malts.  Black body with a small head.  Nice full palate is creamy.  Taste is very chocolate with the right amount of roasted flavor behind that.  Very nice.

Columbus tasting 7 bottle shared by jsquire. Very smooth chocolate and some slight alcohol in the aroma.Pours black with a thin tan head.Lots of big chocolate and some smooth alcohol stood out in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with lots of chocolate in the finish.A very nice brew.

C-Bus 7 Bottle shared by jsquire: Dark brown to black pour with a tan head. Aroma, lots of roasty chocolaty notes. Flavor, chocolate, roasted malts, fruits, a nice roasty bitterness on the finish, some slight coffee. Very nice stuff.

Pours with a black body topped by a medium thick, brown head with a good amount of lacing.  Its slightly sweet and amlty yet a touch sour with slight roasty notes.  Ful bodied and smooth with a dry finish.

22 oz.  Black color.  Chocolate brown head.  Intriguing malt complexity in the nose, with hints of chocolate, fudge and light coffee.  On the palate, its awfully complex, with hints of dried chocolate, light espresso, fruit and mild roast.  Clearly a great stout.

Bottle. Dark black body with a small creamy mocha head. Smells roasty with chalky chocolate, toffee, and cheese. Tastes of bitter roast, oily chocolate, and caramel. Some malt sourness and finishing with mild bitterness. Solid.

bottle, from trade with kenb (I think) Has a 9 or b on in marker on the cap. Good aroma, roasty sweet. I get a bourbon scent, bitter chocolate, dark roast coffee. little woodiness, not an oaked scent just the smell of a plain hunk of board. Blackish brown color, small head that faded quickly, some lacing that disappeared as it warmed. Bitter flavor, like aroma with the bourbon being foremost, maybe call it like malibu rum. bitter coffee and chocolate too. Medium body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, bitter dryish finish. Maybe it was my mood, but I didnt like the way the bourbony thing with it, especially since it doesnt mention it in the description. That said it drinks well and seems almost imperial in nature.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Deep black with small fading brown head.  Hint of coffee and chocolate aromas.  Dry roasted flavor, medium body and a fanastic finish.  Makes you want to take another gulp.

Pours out a jet black color, very minimal highlights with a foamy tan head. First thing that hits you is the coffe ground aroma. Unfortunately, its a one-trick pony and nothing else came from the aroma. Smallish hops in the flavor department, little on flavor as well. I could pick up sweet malts, roasted malts, a bit of dark chocolate and a little hops. Overall I thought it was just an okay stout. Nothing to rave about.

Another free bottle from Ken (kenb).  Now this is what Im talking about!  Pours out a dark brown color with a thick tan head.  Smell is full of roasted malts, dark chooclate, coffee, some hops.  Taste is smooth and rich, very thick mouthfeel.  Reminded me of an imperial stout.  A very well done beer, deserving of its top of the foreign stouts.  Great stuff.
GABF-on tap- Taste is lots of chocolate/coffee a bit acidic, which was OK.  Full body.

22oz bottle via trade with kenb - Thanks Ken! - Pours black with a short tan head that faded fairly quickly.  Aromas of coffee, chocolate and just a touch of black liccorice.   Flavor is coffee, dark baking chocolate, lots of dark fruit, and some cocoa.  There is a little molasses there and maybe a touch of liccorice as well. Full bodied with low carbonation and an oily mouthfeel.  Very nice stout here..

On tap at Pelican Pub and Brewery, Pacific City, OR.  Black colour with tan head.  Choccy malt aroma.  Smooth in mouth, quite grainy/powdery on finish with lots of coffee.  Dark choc, but powdery.  Not bad, intense powdery choc finish.

Bomber, courtesy of kenb. The obligatory chocolate/coffee in high concentration makes up the bulk of the aroma. Strong roasted malt elements follow with am ever so faint hint of brown sugar and chocolate cake. The body is an uncanny stygian black. One of the darker beers youll see. The head starts off a full two fingers thick, but slowly compresses down to a thumb thick mocha affair. The fore features highly concentrated burnt/roasted malt with dark chocolate and dry cocoa notes. Some slightly sulphery blackstrap molasses and nutty notes in the dry chcolatey finish. Great palate. Solid aroma. Decent flavor.

GABF 2006. Black bodied. Nose is chocolate, roasted malts, light molasses, and sugared and creamed coffee. Taste is more roasted malts, light coffee, notes, bittersweet chocolate, and lightly burnt chocolate chip cookies. Mouthfeel has moderate carbonation. Medium overall feel to it. Ends with more choco notes, coffee, roasted malts, and brown sugar. Touch of molasses as well. Nise stuff!

Wow, thanks to KenB for this one.  Pours onxy, no light transmittance, with 1-finger tan head.  Aroma is roasty dark patent malt, chocoff, brown sugar, some molasses and almonds.  Tastes roasty malty, on the dry side, with a rich chocoff, molasses, and cherry note.  Finishes sry, hefty on the palate, roasty, woth more chocolate and coffee.  Very well done, and an elite stout.

On tap at Pelican Pub & Brewery Pacific City OR. this is the one i really wanted to test out. Pours out a black topped with a thick tan head. A great aroma of chocolate and sweet. Very smooth as well. Good stuff.

GABF 2006.  The beer pours to a pitch black body with a nice tan head with decent lacing.  The aroma is semi-sweet chocolate chips, light dark fruit.  The flavor is a charcoal dry roasty chocolate.  Rich roasty palate.

22 oz bottle via Pelican Brewpub. Pours a thick pitch black with a large tan head. Mild aroma of vanilla, cream, and some subtle chocolate. Full bodied. Sweet flavors of creamy oatmeal and chocolate with a roasty bittersweet finish. Well carbonated. My favorite Foreign Stout so far, even surpassing the excellant Lion Stout.

Bottle courtesy of 11026. Opague black with minimal tan head. Aroma and flavor are rather muted chocolate and coffee. Very faint piney hop finish. As it warmed chocolate character increased, but still not enough going on in general. Mouthfeel was a tad too thin and overcarbonated.

Bottle shared by chriso420.  Thanks a lot!  Roasty, slightly chocolate aroma with some milky and anise smells eminating as well.  Mostly opaque black color with a creamy tan-colored head.  Sweetish chocolate roasty start, which turns sweeter and a bit smokier to finish.  Very rich and roasted.  Mmmm, very tasty stuff!
Nice roasted, chocolatey flavor.  Smooth and velvety in the mouth.  Not the thickest but an excellent stout.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2008 Any first impressions?
-A thin but covering foam dissipates onto the opaque blackness.
-Wealthy roasted malts and their dark chocolate acolytes rise distinctly to emulate a specialty sweets shop.
-Chocolate envelops the few coffee beans in a luxurious union only the talented can create.
-The body is huggable (to be polite), full of authentic maltiness, without too much residual sweetness.

What if you dig deeper?
-Sweet berry juice sneaks up behind the maltiness in the aroma.
-It finishes very quietly, which might be its only downfall imho; some more back roastiness or supporting hops would have been fun.
-Hops are of no consequence in my bottle; this is a malt lovers dream stout.
-A rich and serene chocolatey stout which can reach both those looking for session stouts and those looking for nourishment in the form of a pint. Splendid.

Bottles.

Another fine beer from Pelican. Enjoyed a bomber with a friend. Pitch black color with a nice brown head. Huge hops flavor and full robust body that has flavors of toffee and chocolate. Well done indeed

Barrel Draught from the jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 30/09/2005
Black strong in alcohol and slightly rich on the palate. Some dryness in a roast finish.

(bottle - 22 oz) Dark black pour with a medium sized tan head. Aroma is very sweet, much sweeter than a normal stout in my opinion, loaded with malts and roasted chocolate notes. Flavor is very roasty as well with a nice sweet flavor with lots of roasted malts and a nice chocolate middle. Silky smooth and very well crafted. Quite an enjoyable beer.

Black.  Rich black patent aroma has depths of espresso and dark chocolate.  Richly roasty and bitter body with a brilliantly silky milk chocolate finish.  Full body.  Very well rounded, balanced character.  Complex.  This is a fully realized beer.

Pours with a creamy, dense, three-finger thick, full, milk chocolate colored head.  The beer is a pitch black color, nice and opaque.  The aroma is acidic up front; redolent of ample dark malts.  Rich notes of dark chocolate, espresso beans dominate afterwards with sharp, burnt astringent grain husk notes in the finish, that arent nearly as harsh as it might seem.  Actually the finish is quite nice, the overall aroma is quite warm and inviting.

The taste has a sweet chocolate note to it up front, which is quickly dominated by an ample roast character that reminds me of chicory, and black coffee.  The beer has a nice palate fullness to it; coating but not cloying, just thick enough that the contemplation of the upcoming 22oz bottle is not too overwhelming.  The beer finishes with a burnt acidity that actually tends to keep this Imperial Stout a bit lighter than it otherwise would be.  This is pretty light on the hops, at least for this type of beer; there is a bit of bitterness just noticeable under all the dark malts (which means there is probably quite a bit), but not much in the way of any flavor hop additions.  This lets this beer focus on the malt, which in this case is mostly the dark malts.

This beer is quite tasty, but it could definitely use a bit more general malt character; a bit thicker and maltier would make this beer a bit more balanced, but then it would be a bit harder to get through a 22oz bottle.  As this beer warms up a bit it gains a bit more fullness in the mouth, and correspondingly a bit more malt character.  It could still use a bit more, but it is a bit more balanced than it first was when it was 50*F.

Thanks to cmaruschak for the surprise hookup. Deep black color with a thick and foamy brown head that dissipates steadily. The aroma is chocolate and malt, with a subtle vinous character here and there. Rich body, with a nice blend of coffee and cocoa flavors along with roasted malt and hops. The finish is hoppy and nutty and roasty. Very enjoyable from start to finish.

Draught at the brewpub.  Dark black with minimal beige head. Strong roasty coffee aroma. Dry and firmly malty. Its dominated by roasty malt, butbalanced by light grapefruity hops. Long nicely bitter finish. An excellent stout, even though the mouthfeel might be on the clean/hard side.

Bottle. Black color with a small tan head. 
Dark roasted malt aroma with some vanilla and hops. Roasted malt flavor with dark chocolate, hazel nuts and a bitter hop finish.

The cap says 01, so Im guessing this is a 2001 vintage.  Poured black with a creamy brown head.  Aroma of hoppy roasted chocolate, pretty nice.  Taste is bitter roasted coffee and chocolate, but seems somewhat thin.  Perhaps a tad past its prime.

RBSG 2005.

Head is mostly lasting.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, chocolate).

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Light to medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation.

I had this once or twice (such as at GABF) before finally rating it with this bomber, cause...well...I have never seen this as the best Foreign Stout in the world.  Its a pretty nice beer, sure, but...I just kept thinking I was having ho-hum samples, but theyve been fairly consistent.  3.5 is the best sample Ive had, so Ill be generous with my official score and use that one.

22 oz bottle thanks to Secret Santa!  black with brown foam on top, and rich aroma of starchy oatmealy roasted barley.  flavor is a cacaphonous experience of bitter roast and sweet sugar and starch, and a grapefruit cascade-like hops finish that i only really notice at the end.  woody and vinous earthy flavors, nutty and dark.  very good stout!

Bomber.  Pours beautiful and dark with a frothy tan head.  Aroma could have been a little stronger, but was very smooth (can an aroma be smooth??) with a nice combination of chocolate, coffee and a few dark fruits.  Very silky and smooth in the mouth.  It starts off a little roasty with a bit of a kick, but slides down oh so smooth.  Nice and complex with the aforementioned coffee and semisweet chocolate but also a nice helping of vanilla, dark fruits and a little nuttiness.  This is another great one from this great brewery.

Bottle:  Courtesy of Styles.  Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, and light roasted malt.  Pours a dark brown with no transparency and a small tan head.  Vanilla and dark chocolate up front.  Finishes moderately roasty with roasted malt and coffee.

A pitch black beer with a disappearing brown head. The aroma is sweet with lots of chocolate and coffee. The flavor contains lots of chocolate, wood, coffee, and grapefruit, leading to a dry end. But the body is thin.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2011 Dark and mostly black with a tan head. Very appetizing nose ... a big bouquet of chocolate, roast and toast. Chewy, rewarding texture. Very tasty malts, with chocolate, coffee and more. Interesting balance/interplay between sweet, bitter, sour and roast. Bit of tar and char in the background. Solid stout.

GABF 2005. Nearly opaque with dark brown highlights and a rich tan head. Aroma of cocoa, mild coffee, and burnt plum. Flavor beats a great espresso. Has subtle fruity tart acidity. Very pleasing with great depth of character.
(GABF05) Black body with tan head.  Aroma is rich, medium sweet, roasty, coffee. Taste is medium sweet, roasty, coffee, light cocoa.  Watery medium body.
Dark, slight reddish brown head.  Nose prunes, charcoal, and coffee bitterness.  Flavor full of dark fruit sweetness and chocolate, rich and tasty.  Dry and smoky, finishes sweet.

Very vinous aroma with red wine.  Sweet with fermented fruit.  Unfiltered for sure, because my last sip contained something in solid form about the size of a quarter.  I like sediment, but this is going a little far.  Fairly heavy but very easy to drink due to the smooth body.

Beautiful foamy head, lasting and 1cm head covers the not quite opaque black body. Strong chocolate nose, very malty with coffee grains nuances and nutty edges. Very roasty, burnt bread reminiscent. Well "cooked", bold, cocoa powder like. It disappoints a bit in mouth where it has this slightest acid thing going on which doesnt pair all that well with the roastiness and create a rather stale evolution. Plasticy chocolate reminiscent. The hop bitterness is more than fair on the other hand, but the damage is done. Low carbonation, medium bodied. Good stuff.

Sampled from bottle at RBSG 2005 post-Cider Tour Sunday Tiger, Tiger Burning Bright tasting.  Pitch black with lasting thin brown head, little to no lacing...licorice, tar and some creamy sherry in the nose alongside roasty chocolate....body oily, roasty, lightly peppery, touch nutty and vinous.  I dunno, this just didnt really do it.

Tap.  Deepest black in color.  The head is quite dense and creamy, not unlike a nitro pour.  Head lifespan would be hours if I didnt drink the beer, terrific lacing is left behind.  Aroma is strongly of roasted grains, lurking in the background I thought I picked up some fusel alcohols, just hints here and there of Isopropyl.  Medium to full bodied.  Nice medium to low carbonation level.  Flavor is packed full of roastiness, nuts, chocolate.  Hopping is excellent and approaching over the top.  Damn nice beer.

Alcohol, sweet marzipan notes to the roasty aroma.  Opaque black body with low but lasting tan head.  Dry, roasty, somewhat grapey flaovur with a bittersweet chocolate aftertaste.  Medium body with moderate carbonation.  Bottle sampled at the post-RBSG05 hotel room tasting.

07.10.05  Bomber, RBSG.  Black.  Medium brown head fades to film.  Lots of vanilla, dark chocolate, bitterly roasty.  Much like burnt pumpernickle toast spread with nutella dipped in prune juice and eaten with coffee.  Luscious.

RBSG2005, Post-dégustation.  Couleur noire foncée tapissée dune grosse mousse crémeuse adhérant à la paroi du verre.  Lait au chocolat, cacao et malt grillé observent le houblon semblant fatigué.  En bouche, malt hautement grillé et chocolat suivi dune touche de fumée grise, propre à un feu de camp.  Corps dépaisseur moyenne, faible carbonatation.
This is such a great stout.  I hope on day I am able to brew a stout this good.  WOW this is just the best.

Pours black with a thin chocolate collored head.  Smells of chocolate coffee and malts.  Tastes awesome, sweet malt/chocolate taste and a slight coffee bitter.  Aftertatse starts bitter and become a wonderful chocolate sweet.  Great Stout
Dark, Dark Black Coloring with Espresso Ring.  Dark Roasts....Medium Bodied and Dry Hoppy Ending.  Great Stout With Good Character.

This is such a nice stout, out of the bottle or off tap this is always impressive. Pours black with a tall tan head. Good roasted flavors and aroma with light chocolate and nice coffee throughout. Very smooth and creamy texture and medium bitter finish.

Fruit malt aroma, on the second sniff chocolate becomes evident, nice full roasted malt chocolate taste, with a coffee bean aftertaste. As it warms the taste changes to that of a dark chocolate. Very satisfying,which I didnt have to send out for it

Poured an opaque black color with some red around the edges, a small tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  I will have to agree with hop dog in that both the taste and aroma included chocolate and roasted malts, though not much more.  A nice stout, not sure its a dry.  Thanks Steve!
Poured a dark black color with a smaller dark brown (almost reddish) head. Aromas and tastes of roasted matls and chocolate. Lightly bitter coffee finish.
Damn near black color with no head.  Burnt coffee aroma.  Scorched roasts in the taste with an almost salty finish.  Very interesting and damn tasty!
Aroma is a little faint. Wonderful flavor. Fully opaque body. No head, great lace. Pepper finish. Nice bite.

Bottle pours black, dark brown highlights, large tannish foamy head, with fairly attractive lacing.   Coffee, roasted malts, and a semi-sweet or dry chocolate aroma.   Burnt malts, coffee, and bakers chocolate on the tongue.   A bit chalky, but definitely dry.   Good body, moderate mouthfeel.   Long finish, just as it started.   I think this to be a great example of the style.   Not overly dry, with great body and flavor.   Could be a bit thicker, but good nonetheless.

Clear and dark brown with a red hue. Light brown creamy head that leaves a nice ring in the glass. Dry bitter chocolate aroma with sweet vanilla and strawberry(?). Exceptional taste... light roasted chocolate. .Leaves a roasted metallic feeling on the tongue. Palate is so-so. A little thin. But Im all about the flavor of this one. Very good.

Pitch black, small tan creamy head.  Nose is loaded with bitter-sweet chocolate, vanilla, roasted coffee with a dark fruit edge to it.  Well balanced, bittered, with burnt expresso and airy bitter chocolate taking the reigns.  Medium bodied, fizzy carbonation, semi-dry, bitter finish.  Finally an awesome stout thats not Imperial....

Opaque black with a medium kahki head. Roasty, cocoa aroma with some nice notes of licorice. Dry and roasty, some dark fruity notes. Roasted coffe bean flavor in the finish as well as some licorice. Solid stout.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2006 Bottle... This beer rocks...Midnight black with a small, creamy, very well-tanned head. Good retention. The nose is of milk chocolate and vanilla, cherries, a touch of port and a whisper of buttermilk. Perfectly balanced and very burnt with notes of dusty cocoa powder and espresso grounds. Moderately bitter. Medium-bodied with a very creamy mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, bitter finish.  World class brew from the fine folks in Oregon!

on tap at the brewery. pretty damn black wth a thick brown head that lingered. aroma of powder chocolate and instant coffee. quite sweet chocolate cream flavour with some burnt stonefruit and powdery dryness. nice stuff indeed and a nice place for a beer

Hello there excellent brew, very nice to meet you.  This is a world class beer IMO.    Nice roasted malt aroma with faint hops.  Pitch black in color.  Pours with a nice, thick, fluffy head that lingers.  This is a full bodied brew, almost thick like a milkshake.  Nice roasted malt flavor with a topnotch assembly of hops.  Long bitter finish. Exquisite brew.  Thanks to Derek Arent for the sample.

Appearance: deepest,darkest black, wholly opaque, with a considerable, creamy, thick, roasty brown head. 
Aroma: dark, bitter, nicely toasted, with fruity undercurrents, an almost perfect nose for a stout.
Taste: good smattering of hops up front, but smooth soon after. Very firm-bodied, with recurring fruity aspects, (Im tasting cherries...you?),
 though still dark, acidic, and bittersweet. Full of lasting flavor, too. the name, however, had me anticipating a monsoon of flavor, like an Imperial Stout, and that is not the case. An excellent "regular" stout, shall we say, but one still abundant with flavor. Quite nice, actually, and remarkably similar to Guinness Extra Stout.

Solid. Solid in almost all respects. That certain elements are NOT outstanding makes this all the more so. No cloying sweetness. No lingering burnt malt. Balance. Sublime balance with cohesion and clarity and focus and and and and ... just lovely stuff. What a marvel.
Poured dark with nice orange highlights at the rims. Head was khaki and faded quickly. Aromas of earth and cocoa. Nice, thick chocolateness. Great mouthfeel. Warmed nicely as well.

Notes of early November.  Big and very roasted aroma with a vinyl rain poncho smell there too.  100% opaque.  Palate the fine but not distinguished.  I have a few doubts, but mostly pretty good and certainly worth acquiring.

Bottle. Nose is strong of chocolate and grass. Very odd, but nice. Typical stout flavors-coffee, dark malt, and chocolate. Very mild for a stout. Malty/cereal taste. A mild hop bite on the back end. Not bad but not mind blowing.
Poured black with thin tan head...smelled mintychocograss...roasted coffee chocolate taste...a very mild stout...
black with a firm light brown head. nose is of cocoa with a touch of mint/grass. raosted flavor of chocolate and bitter. finish is a nice subtle chocolate.
Dark brown pour. Good head retention. Nice roasted nose. Very solid dry stout. Dark roast coffee bitterness. Bitter chocolate. Excellent rendition.

Aroma:  strong dark coffee, slight smoke, bittersweet chocolate, chocolate malts

Appearance:  dark brown, tan head, lacing

Flavor:  smoke, bakers chocolate, dark-bitter coffee, slight creaminess, fresh hopiness

Palate:  very bubbly, dry-hoppy aftertaste, as well as, a bitter sweet chocolate aftertaste
Good rpasted aroma.  Slightly roasted and well balanced.  Good malt finish.
